bug.short_desc: TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so mismatches non-TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so when linking to LLVM on s390x

long_desc.thetext:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #1185952 +++
When being built with LLVM support on s390x, PostgreSQL 11, 12 and 13 most of the time, but not always fails with the following error:
/usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: @GLIBCXX_3.4.11: TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so mismatches non-TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so: error adding symbols: bad value collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status make[2]: *** [../../../../src/Makefile.shlib:309: llvmjit.so] Error 1
We suspect a race condition that might be related to link time optimisation. So far it was not reproducible in local builds, only in OBS workers.
For the details gathered so far, see bug 1185952 comment 39 and following.

Thank you for this bug report, Reinhard!
Additional important information from the other bug report:
Aaron Puchert: Since it comes from ld (or collect2?) and that's an LTO link, I suppose it might be a race condition. I agree, it should be a separate bug. Maybe add Michael Matz for binutils and Martin Liska for GCC LTO. IBM tends to have weaker memory models, and that race might just not materialize with the stronger model of x86.
Michael Matz: I was involved for that already. I never was able to reproduce it with a local build (on s390x of course), with none of the postgres packages. And triggering a rebuild of an affected package, even if it got to the same build machine, sometime also makes it build through (just to fail on the next rebuilds again). So, it's most definitely a race somewhere, but without being at least somewhat locally reproducable it's hopeless.
One question to the SUSE people here. I know, that you have got also a Beta version now. Is this bug report reproducible with SLES?
The build is failing with PostgreSQL11 at the moment. Log: https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/openSUSE:Factory:zSystems/postgresql11/standard/s390x

(In reply to Sarah Kriesch from comment #2)
> Is this bug report reproducible with SLES?
I don't think I've seen it happen there so far, but AFAICS even the upcoming SLE15-SP4 is still on llvm11, so the situation is not comparable. Maybe we should check if it also happens with llvm11 on openSUSE, or only with llvm12.
One thing I noticed is that the VMs for s390x in OBS seem to be a lot slower than the ones that build SLE, and maybe also compared to the ones that Michael was using in his manual tests where he couldn't reproduce it. So, maybe the race is more likely to get triggered on less powerful machines.

There's not really anything "racy" in how GCC LTO is set up - the actual error message from ld is also not exactly helpful, referencing libLLVM.so twice:
[ 994s] /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: @GLIBCXX_3.4.11: TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so mismatches non-TLS refe rence in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so [ 994s] /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so: error adding symbols: bad value
But given that /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so is not built when postgresql is the error should be visible there. There's exactly two TLS references in libLLVM.so.12
23: 0000000000000000 0 TLS GLOBAL DEFAULT UND _ZSt11__once_call@GLIBCXX_3.4.11 (16) 29: 0000000000000000 0 TLS GLOBAL DEFAULT UND _ZSt15__once_callable@GLIBCXX_3.4.11 (16)
so just speculating that the 'ld' error is bogus and the second reference to '/usr/lib64/libLLVM.so' should really be to sth else, like an object from the link command-line as built by
g++ -Wall -Wmissing-prototypes -Wpointer-arith -Wdeclaration-after-stat ement -Wendif-labels -Wmissing-format-attribute -Wformat-security -fno-strict-al iasing -fwrapv -fexcess-precision=standard -Wno-format-truncation -Wno-stringop- truncation -O2 -g -m64 -fmessage-length=0 -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-protector -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fPIC -shared -o llvmjit.so llvmj it.o llvmjit_error.o llvmjit_inline.o llvmjit_wrap.o llvmjit_expr.o llvmjit_defo rm.o -L../../../../src/port -L../../../../src/common -flto=auto -ffat-lto-objec ts -L/usr/lib64 -Wl,--as-needed -lLLVM
to simplify things I would also try to remove the -Wl,--as-needed and try to filter out -ffat-lto-objects from the parts that don't need it.
OTOH the error is from _bfd_elf_merge_symbol but calling that with two same bfds is a bit odd.

(In reply to Reinhard Max from comment #4) > One thing I noticed is that the VMs for s390x in OBS seem to be a lot slower > than the ones that build SLE, and maybe also compared to the ones that > Michael was using in his manual tests where he couldn't reproduce it. So, > maybe the race is more likely to get triggered on less powerful machines.
PostgreSQL11 has got no constraints file in OBS at the moment. We can adapt it if we know the correct requirements (same as SLE).

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #5) > There's not really anything "racy" in how GCC LTO is set up - the actual
That's correct. As usual we use the term 'race' for anything unexplainable and unreproducable, where data doesn't match anything reasonable. We could call it faulty memory, or moon phase, or bad luck, or maybe undefined behaviour :-)
> error message from ld is also not exactly helpful, referencing libLLVM.so > twice:
Actually it's helpful a bit in showing that something strange is going on:
> [ 994s] > /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: > @GLIBCXX_3.4.11: TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so mismatches non-TLS > reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so
Here, the symbol for which there are TLS and non-TLS references is mentioned, it's '@GLIBCXX_3.4.11'. That is of course not any sensible symbol, it's an empty symbol name with a symbol version, or the symbol version itself interpreted as symbol name.
My guess is that the linker plugin does something strange (aka undefined), either caused by a problem in llvms use of it, or in ld. It manipulates the symbol tables and the above definitely is something strange with the symbol table.
> [ 994s] > /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: > /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so: error adding symbols: bad value > > But given that /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so is not built when postgresql is the > error should be visible there. There's exactly two TLS references in > libLLVM.so.12 > > 23: 0000000000000000 0 TLS GLOBAL DEFAULT UND > _ZSt11__once_call@GLIBCXX_3.4.11 (16) > 29: 0000000000000000 0 TLS GLOBAL DEFAULT UND > _ZSt15__once_callable@GLIBCXX_3.4.11 (16)
No no, if it were anything you can see directly in the input files, then the error would be reproducable. Of course the inputs are completely fine.
> to simplify things I would also try to remove the -Wl,--as-needed and try to > filter out -ffat-lto-objects from the parts that don't need it. > > OTOH the error is from _bfd_elf_merge_symbol but calling that with two > same bfds is a bit odd.
All the more reason to believe in some error of the linker plugin.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #5) > > OTOH the error is from _bfd_elf_merge_symbol but calling that with two > > same bfds is a bit odd. > > All the more reason to believe in some error of the linker plugin.
Yes, I suspect some memory corruption/overflow issue is at play. It does seem that 'llvm' merely acts as source code providing the linker inputs and the compile is entirely under GCCs control.

(In reply to Sarah Kriesch from comment #6)
> PostgreSQL11 has got no constraints file in OBS at the moment. We can adapt > it if we know the correct requirements (same as SLE).
None of the PostgreSQL packages on openSUSE or SLE has a constraints file.

(In reply to Reinhard Max from comment #9) > None of the PostgreSQL packages on openSUSE or SLE has a constraints file. Then SUSE has got larger VMs as a default for building packages. The smallest openSUSE building instances have got 4GB of memory.
I have to say, that there is an open bug report because of the double memory usage with GCC on the mainframe: https://bugzilla.opensuse.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1188441

I found an additional package with the same problem today. Rust1.55 is not buildable with this LLVM output: "-Wl,--no-whole-archive" "-Wl,--start-group" "-L" "/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/rustc-1.55.0-src/build/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/stage1/lib/rustlib/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/lib" "-Wl,-Bdynamic" "-lstd-9230439e7f86be05" "-Wl,--end-group" "-Wl,-Bstatic" "/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/rustc-1.55.0-src/build/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/stage1/lib/rustlib/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/lib/libcompiler_builtins-969714438fc667c3.rlib" "-Wl,-Bdynamic" "-lLLVM" "-lstdc++" "-lgcc_s" "-lutil" "-lrt" "-lpthread" "-lm" "-ldl" "-lc" "-Wl,--eh-frame-hdr" "-Wl,-znoexecstack" "-L" "/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/rustc-1.55.0-src/build/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/stage1/lib/rustlib/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/lib" "-o" "/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/rustc-1.55.0-src/build/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/stage1-rustc/s390x-unknown-linux-gnu/release/deps/librustc_driver-8e50d53b77b458b3.so" "-shared" "-Wl,-zrelro" "-Wl,-znow" "-Wl,-O1" "-nodefaultlibs" "-Wl,-z,relro,-z,now" [18428s] = note: /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: @GLIBCXX_3.4.11: TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so mismatches non-TLS reference in /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so [18428s] /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/11/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/libLLVM.so: error adding symbols: bad value [18428s] collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status [18428s] [18428s] [18429s] [18429s] Did not run successfully: exit status: 1
https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/openSUSE:Factory:zSystems/rust1.55/standard/s390x

This is an autogenerated message for openQA integration by the openqa_review script:
This bug is still referenced in a failing openQA test: textmode-server https://openqa.opensuse.org/tests/1944822
To prevent further reminder comments one of the following options should be followed: 1. The test scenario is fixed by applying the bug fix to the tested product or the test is adjusted 2. The openQA job group is moved to "Released" or "EOL" (End-of-Life) 3. The bugref in the openQA scenario is removed or replaced, e.g. `label:wontfix:boo1234`

Last month was no time for doing something on this issue. Now I have tested it with a constraints file and you were right! It is working as a workaround with the definition of 8GB of memory in the constraints file. It has been chosen systems with 4GB without any system requirements and if SUSE is using only 8GB of memory to above, you can not reproduce it. You have got a SR now.
I accepted that SR and expanded the fix to all versions, but unfortunately the error still happens at least on versions 13 and 14 (11 and 12 are still waiting for a compliant worker).

Thank you for accepting it! I was a little bit surprised, because I had a successful build in my home project yesterday.
I will analyze that deeper today. We have got successful builds of Rust now. Therefore, I will compare these changes. Perhaps I can find something useful for our problem with PostgreSQL.
I just had a successful manual build on a VM with less than 2GB of RAM, so I don't think it depends on the amount of memory.
FWIW, I repeated this 5 to 10 times during the day under the same VM and never got a failure.

I have checked with Google today for the TLS error message. There was also a hint to replace the compiler with another version as a possible solution. Additionally, I took a look at Fedora and their patches for PostgreSQL13.4. They had an openssl build issue. TLS is integrated in openssl. I do not know, whether that could be a solution. These patches are from PostgreSQL Maintainers. Therefore, they should be also upstream available: https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/postgresql/c/21b8d7a7d28c2765e94ab9c8e4f0b155e2bf7f3c?branch=rawhide
"TLS" in the linker error at hand means Thread Local Storage, not Transport Layer Security. ;)
I believe, that I create a bugreport upstream at LLVM. I found something equal to that for PowerPC.
Bugreport at LLVM is created

(In reply to Sarah Kriesch from comment #20) > I believe, that I create a bugreport upstream at LLVM. I found something > equal to that for PowerPC. Hmm, it might certainly be a bug in how LLVM is set up, but for now it looks much more like a bug in either GCC or binutils:
(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > My guess is that the linker plugin does something strange (aka undefined), > either caused by a problem in llvms use of it, or in ld. It manipulates the > symbol tables and the above definitely is something strange with the symbol > table. > [...] > All the more reason to believe in some error of the linker plugin. That's the linker plugin of GCC.
(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #8) > Yes, I suspect some memory corruption/overflow issue is at play. It does > seem that 'llvm' merely acts as source code providing the linker inputs and > the compile is entirely under GCCs control. But I have to retract my initial suspicion that this is probably a race condition. Memory errors can also be sporadic due to allocation address indeterminism. And unlike LLVM's (Thin)LTO, GCC's spawns separate processes instead of threads, right? So that would make a race very unlikely.

The openQA job group is moved to "Released" or "EOL" (End-of-Life) 3. The bugref in the openQA scenario is removed or replaced, e.g. `label:wontfix:boo1234`

I created the bug report at LLVM because I found this TLS related bug for PowerPC there: https://bugs.llvm.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15359
But I can create it at GCC instead.
New upstream bug is created.

I believe more and more that the bfd ld is responsible for this and other issues in OBS.qore-ssh2-module is also failing with an "error: ld returned 1 exit status" after an undefined reference. That is another case of undefined references with functions, but it contains the same error structure.

That's a very generic error message. Nothing like this can be inferred from it. If you believe it's related, please create a new bug report with full information, in particular full command line and error message.
Does anybody know the difference between openSUSE VMs in OBS and SUSE internal VMs (besides of less memory)? Adding memory requirements did not help and IBM wants to reproduce the bug now.

Let's first check if there is an actual difference in behavior between OBS and IBS workers. I think so far we only know that PostgreSQL fails with llvm13 on Factory in OBS and succeeds with llvm11 on SLE-15 in IBS, so the difference that matters might be llvm13 vs. llvm12 or Factory vs. SLE-15 rather than OBS vs. IBS.
I've set up a branch of postgresql14 in IBS to check this, but Factory seems to be in a major rebuild there right now, so it might take overnight until I get a result.
Andreas Krebbel tried it with building PostgreSQL and Rust in containers. He does not receive any error messages with that.
It is also not reproducible on Fedora 33 as well as SLES 15 SP3 with osc commands. It works only on openSUSE Tumbleweed.

I collected some more info while doing test runs for bug 1188896.
I used IBS (OBS is too busy) for test builds of postgresql14, against oS:F:zSystems and my kernel-default branch with the potential fix for bug 1188896 applied.
25/29 succeeded, 3/29 failed with the error reported here and 1/29 got stuck badly even before the build started. On OBS it seems to be worse, maybe just because of additional load or because the workers have less memory and parallel jobs configured.
To get some more info, I patched the .spec file to retry make once after it failed. To my surprise, that failed reliably still (2/2 times), so it appears like it's probably reproducible after it happens once.
I also made it upload libLLVM.so* and the jit/llvm/ directory after the (successful or failed) build. Also to my surprise, the contents are completely identical, just that the failed builds don't have libllvmjit.so inside.

I tried it already with an additional constraints file and 8GB of memory. That did not help. If I know it correctly, 12GB is the highest available amount of memory for mainframe OBS workers.
Rust1.54 is also affected (with 8GB configured memory) from this issue.
If the compilation needs so much of memory, that is a nice reason for me to request for storage for the community from IBM (via the GCC bug report). ^^

But shouldn't we see stuff like OOM kills if there was a RAM shortage?
Could it be a build parallelity issue? How about trying a "make -j1" build to see if that makes results more stable — either all succeeding or all failing? That would of course also reduce the memory footprint compared to parallel builds.

(In reply to Reinhard Max from comment #35) > But shouldn't we see stuff like OOM kills if there was a RAM shortage? That is something I have also expected. But I can also reference Andreas Krebbel with: > Why only 4/8GB? Isn't this way too low for building things like rust with lto and everything?
> I've successfully built rust1.54 and postgresql14 several times in an opensuse > tumbleweed container. So I would suspect either the kernel or the guest setup > you are using. Could it perhaps be that ld processes got oom killed and have left half-complete binaries which triggered the error then? > > In the current logs I don't see the ld issue anymore. Apparently you already gave it more memory and the behavior changed due to that?
>> osc co openSUSE:Factory:zSystems/postgresql14 >> cd openSUSE\:Factory\:zSystems/postgresql14/ >> osc build --vm-type=kvm --vm-memory=4G > > Tried with these commands. Build fails due to OOM killer with 4GB and 8GB. > Package builds fine starting with 12GB. In none of the cases I got the ld error.
I had a call with Ihno in the last hour. The capacity should not be any problem. We can test it with any required constraints. But I would suggest, if that is really the reason, I will write that into the GCC bug and create a new bug report for IBM, that gcc/LLVM requires more than double of the memory in comparison to x86.

It seems that 12GB of memory has helped as a workaround for PostgreSQL14: https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:AdaLovelace:branches:openSUSE:Factory:zSystems/postgresql14
Reinhard, should we do that also for the other versions? Sometimes this issue has also exists for 13 as an example.

(In reply to Sarah Kriesch from comment #37)
> Reinhard, should we do that also for the other versions?
Yes, if it really helps.
> Sometimes this issue has also exists for 13 as an example.
I think it happened with all llvm-capable versions.

(In reply to Reinhard Max from comment #35) > But shouldn't we see stuff like OOM kills if there was a RAM shortage?
Yes. (Not 100% true, but close enough in this case).
> Could it be a build parallelity issue? How about trying a "make -j1" build > to see if that makes results more stable — either all succeeding or all > failing? That would of course also reduce the memory footprint compared to > parallel builds.
In my tests, it worked fine when building the llvmjit backend first without parallelism and then the rest. Though the randomness of the failure makes all tests questionable to a certain extent.
make -C src/backend/jit/llvm PACKAGE_TARNAME=%pgname make %{?_smp_mflags} PACKAGE_TARNAME=%pgname
What points against (make) parallelism as the cause of this though is that the objects being linking are identical in working and failed builds and a retry after a failed link also fails.

(In reply to Reinhard Max from comment #38) > (In reply to Sarah Kriesch from comment #37) > > Yes, if it really helps. I have watched the builds of my Submit Request for PostgreSQL14 with additional capacity. It seems, that it has really helped. https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/939954

This bug had been escalated via the Linux Distributions Working Group because Rust has been also affected and Alpine Linux was not able to build for s390x anymore. Ulrich Weigand came into action and provides some help with fixes now. I hope, that these ones will come also upstream the next time.

bug.short_desc: Automatic setup of gdb prettyprintters

long_desc.thetext:
Installing libc*-pp-gcc* packages for prettyprinters in gdb. Does not configure gdb to load the prettyprinters by default.
Have to add lines to ~/.gdbinit file.
% cat ~/.gdbinit python import sys sys.path.insert(0, '/usr/share/gcc-9/python') from libstdcxx.v6.printers import register_libstdcxx_printers register_libstdcxx_printers (None) end %

We don't provide any libc*-pp-* packages. If you are talking about the libstdc++6-pp-gcc* packages, then the following holds:
The pretty-printers are auto-loaded when a program using libstdc++.so.6 is started under gdb. E.g.:
% gdb /usr/bin/zypper ... (gdb) start Temporary breakpoint 1, 0x00005555555f5440 in main () (gdb) info auto-load gdb-scripts: No auto-load scripts. libthread-db: No auto-loaded libthread-db. local-gdbinit: Local .gdbinit file was not found. python-scripts: Loaded Script Yes /usr/share/gdb/auto-load/usr/lib64/libglib-2.0.so.0.6600.2-gdb.py Yes /usr/share/gdb/auto-load/usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6.0.29-gdb.py
That libstdc++.so.6.0.29-gdb.py file is part of the respective libstdc++6-pp-gcc* package. If you really want to load the libstdc++ prettyprinters without a debuggee, or with one that doesn't link against libstdc++, then indeed you need to load them manually. That all is by design, we don't want to load these pretty-printers into all gdb sessions.
If you have a case where that auto-loading and pretty-printing doesn't work despite the debuggee being a C++ program, feel free to reopen with more details.

Hi,
>> If you are talking about the libstdc++6-pp-gcc* packages
Sorry, I did mean those. Not the ones in I mentioned.
I will test with the "info auto-load" command you mention.

When issuing the "info auto-load", I don't get the same result.
erniep@gracie:~$ gdb /usr/bin/zypper ... (gdb) start Temporary breakpoint 1 at 0x893e0 Starting program: /usr/bin/zypper [Thread debugging using libthread_db enabled] Using host libthread_db library "/lib64/libthread_db.so.1". [New Thread 0x7fffee45a700 (LWP 2392)]
Thread 1 "Zypp-main" hit Temporary breakpoint 1, 0x00005555554893e0 in main () (gdb) info auto-load gdb-scripts: No auto-load scripts. libthread-db: No auto-loaded libthread-db. local-gdbinit: Local .gdbinit file was not found. python-scripts: Loaded Script Yes /usr/share/gdb/auto-load/usr/lib64/libglib-2.0.so.0.7000.4-gdb.py (gdb)
I don't see "libstdc++.so.6.0.29-gdb.py" in the Leap15.4 release. Maybe it's in TW.
I have these packages installed.
erniep@gracie:~$ zypper search -i | grep libstdc++ i | libstdc++-devel | The system GNU C++ development files | package i+ | libstdc++6 | The standard C++ shared library | package i | libstdc++6-devel-gcc7 | Include Files and Libraries mandatory for Development | package i | libstdc++6-devel-gcc9 | Include Files and Libraries mandatory for Development | package i | libstdc++6-pp-gcc9 | GDB pretty printers for the C++ standard library | package
And these files are in the "auto-load" directory.
erniep@gracie:~$ ls -l /usr/share/gdb/auto-load/usr/lib64/ total 84 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 197 May 7 16:40 libglib-2.0.so.0.7000.4-gdb.py -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 200 May 7 16:40 libgobject-2.0.so.0.7000.4-gdb.py -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 65767 Mar 16 11:17 libpython3.6m.so.1.0-gdb.py -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2374 Nov 2 2021 libstdc++.so.6.0.24-gdb.py -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2374 Apr 20 2020 libstdc++.so.6.0.28-gdb.py erniep@gracie:~$
I'm not clear on how the auto-load works. I see these files in /etc.
erniep@gracie:~$ ls -lR /etc/gdbinit /etc/gdbinit.d/ -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 211 Jul 28 2019 /etc/gdbinit
/etc/gdbinit.d/: total 4 lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 24 May 1 2020 go.gdb -> /etc/alternatives/go.gdb erniep@gracie:~$
Let me know if you need more information.

(In reply to Ernie Pasveer from comment #3) > I don't see "libstdc++.so.6.0.29-gdb.py" in the Leap15.4 release. Maybe it's > in TW.
Yeah, the specific versions will differ on different systems.
> i+ | libstdc++6 | The standard C++ shared > library | package
So, which package version is this? (rpm -q libstdc++6)
> i | libstdc++6-devel-gcc7 | Include Files and > Libraries mandatory for Development | package > i | libstdc++6-devel-gcc9 | Include Files and > Libraries mandatory for Development | package > i | libstdc++6-pp-gcc9 | GDB pretty printers for > the C++ standard library | package > > And these files are in the "auto-load" directory. > > erniep@gracie:~$ ls -l /usr/share/gdb/auto-load/usr/lib64/ > -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2374 Nov 2 2021 libstdc++.so.6.0.24-gdb.py > -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2374 Apr 20 2020 libstdc++.so.6.0.28-gdb.py
So, you have autoloads for 6.0.24 and 6.0.28, now we need to find out which libstdc++.so you have on your system. ls -l /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.*
My guess (!) is that you have libstdc++.so.6.0.29, which would be from either gcc10 or gcc11 (the above rpm -q command will tell us). In that case you need to install the pretty-printers for the according gcc version as well, not just the ones for gcc9.
Background: the auto-load is using a very specific version, major.minor.micro, and all three need to match for gdb to auto-load something. The system-libstdc++6 (the one installed into /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6) is regularly updated from time to time (in SLE and hence Leap), to come from newer and newer gcc versions. (This doesn't force you to also use newer GCC compilers, as libstdc++ is backward compatible, so you can happily continue to use gcc9, if you wish). As soon as that update happens the already installed gdb pretty- printers won't match the version anymore (even though they might factually continue to work just fine when loaded manually, but that can't be guaranteed), and so one also needs to update the -pp- package. That latter step doesn't happen automatically yet, we're trying to find a solution for that. But until then you need to install the matching -pp- package yourself.
So, depending on what rpm -q libstdc++6 tells you do: % zypper in libstdc++6-pp-gcc11 (or -gcc10). (this will probably require you to de-install the pp-gcc9 package, but that is no problem as it doesn't match your libstdc++6 anymore anyway)

libstdc++6-pp-gcc11 also supplements the corresponding libstdc++6 and gdb but only the latest update adds some required Obsoletes to make that actually work.
I suppose Leap 15.4 lacks that still? rpm -q libstdc++6 would tell.

And the result of the "ls" command.

Interesting - the supplements alongside with the obsoletes should have pulled libstdc++6-pp-gcc11.
Interestingly enough it didn't for me either. Huh. Surprise?!
Ah, I always do zypper update -t patch, but it seems only zypper update will process the supplements.
So,

does

The following 3 packages are going to be REMOVED: libstdc++6-pp-gcc10 libstdc++6-pp-gcc10-32bit ...
while zypper update -t patch already installed libstdc++6 from gcc11 for me.
Maybe I'm doing it wrong. You, too?

Sorry, I'm not sure what you're asking me to do. But I ran these commands...

erniep@gracie:~$ sudo zypper update -r 17 Repository '17' not found by its alias, number, or URI. Use 'zypper repos' to get the list of defined repositories. erniep@gracie:~$

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2021-45078: binutils: out-of-bounds write in stab_xcoff_builtin_type() in stabs.c

long_desc.thetext:
rh#2033715
stab_xcoff_builtin_type in stabs.c in GNU Binutils through 2.37 allows attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer overflow) or possibly have unspecified other impact, as demonstrated by an out-of-bounds write. NOTE: this issue exists because of an incorrect fix for CVE-2018-12699.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=28694
Upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=161e87d12167b1e36193385485c1f6ce92f74f02
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2033715 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-45078 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2021-45078 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=28694 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=161e87d12167b1e36193385485c1f6ce92f74f02

Affected codestreams: - SUSE:Carwos:1 - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update - SUSE:SLE-12:Update - SUSE:SLE-15:Update - SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update
Also affected on openSUSE: - openSUSE:Factory
I'm pinging Michael on Slack, since he still has to reply on the old bsc#1098941 I have the feeling he doesn't get BZ notification.

This issue is one of the normal fuzzing pseudo-CVEs of binutils. We don't do active fixes for these, instead they will be fixed as part of the annual toolchain update by a binutils version update. The next one is due in autumn 2022. We don't fix these for SLE-11 anymore.
Background: to actually be affected by this problem (which is simply a normal bug processing invalid input) in any security relevant setting someone would need to feed random content from an outsider in an uncontrolled fashion to some command line tools of binutils. It only has a CVE entry because the fuzzers like to collect such numbers and because noone is disputing these CVEs.
So, officiall in progress, but there won't be anything done except the binutils version update later this year.

Hi Michael,
could you provide a more accurate deadline about this update and which codestreams will receive such a version update? Since we consider this security bug important, we want to have this fixed on all the codestreams Carlos mentioned in comment 1.

see his email on security-team.
SUSE:SLE-12:Update and SUSE:SLE-15:Update currnetly receive yearly version updates.

(In reply to Gianluca Gabrielli from comment #4) > could you provide a more accurate deadline about this update
Not really, no. If we extrapolate from the past it will occurr between October and December 2022.
> and which codestreams will receive such a version update?
SLE-12 and SLE-15.
> Since we consider this security bug important,
Based on which criteria is this considered important, and by whom? I certainly don't consider it important, based on the attack vector and how the setup must be for that attack vector to be applicable.
> we want to have this fixed on all the codestreams > Carlos mentioned in comment 1.

valgrind objdump -g oob_write
should NOT report "Invalid write of size 8"
I tested SLE15 SP3 just now and 2.37 is not fixed ... so the CVE page is incorrect. I will adjust it.

bug.short_desc: GCC linker performance compared to other linkers is lacking.

long_desc.thetext:
Within SUSE we exclusively use GCC and it's linker during compilation. This not only affects C, but C++, Rust and other languages. Linking is a significant part of the time taken during compilation, and also has direct impact on our developers time and our power usage and CPU consumption within OBS/IBS.
The performance of the default linker on SUSE however, is lacking compared to other options. This has been well documented publicly, and whole projects like https://github.com/rui314/mold#readme have been created to improve this.
Because the default linker is slow by comparison to mold or lld, this has a direct financial impact on our business, the time of our engineers, our energy usage and cpu consumption, and the experience of our customers who are developers.
I believe that we should:
* Significantly improve the performance of our default linker * OR consider using a different linker by default that has better performance

"it's linker" is simply what is installed as 'ld' which happens to be the BFD linker implemented by binutils btw.
Note mold uses multithreading which, in OBS via -jN, has its own issues when doing multiple links in parallel. It might be interesting to compare CPU time here, not only wall clock time (for the energy part of the "cost" cited).

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > "it's linker" is simply what is installed as 'ld' which happens to be the > BFD linker implemented by binutils btw. > > Note mold uses multithreading which, in OBS via -jN, has its own issues when > doing multiple links in parallel. It might be interesting to compare CPU > time > here, not only wall clock time (for the energy part of the "cost" cited).
Well, the "cost" of an engineer is also a thing, so time to complete also matters.

(In reply to William Brown from comment #2) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > > "it's linker" is simply what is installed as 'ld' which happens to be the > > BFD linker implemented by binutils btw. > > > > Note mold uses multithreading which, in OBS via -jN, has its own issues when > > doing multiple links in parallel. It might be interesting to compare CPU > > time > > here, not only wall clock time (for the energy part of the "cost" cited). > > Well, the "cost" of an engineer is also a thing, so time to complete also > matters.
If the cost of an engineer would matter we would provide them with faster machines to work on. But sure, there are always many aspects of "cost".
Currently the BFD linker just works while possible replacements all have some issues and we definitely do not have the man-power to fully maintain two linkers.

I don't quite see what the specific bug report here is. William: do you have a concrete problem with ld.bfd during your work? If so, please provide details.
If this problem report is merely to make us aware that mold exists: yes, we know. We track its progress on and off and one of our team contributed bug and feature requests to make it more usable for the distro. Right now it can't be used on all architectures we need, and hence is unfeasible as default linker. Even if that were fixed, it has different tradeoffs than BFD ld, which might make it never feasible as a whole-sale default replacement for distro use; that remains to be seen.
Either way, changing the default linker is nothing we would ever consider for SLE15 SP4, which this bug report is created against. Even if it were for SLE-next, at this point we can't even begin to consider changing the default (functionality first, speed second) and wouldn't maintain (more than best effort) two linkers.
So, considering all this, is your request basically "please speed up BFD ld somehow"?

> So, considering all this, is your request basically "please speed up BFD ld somehow"?
Yes. The request is "please make the linker faster".

> I don't quite see what the specific bug report here is. William: do you have a concrete problem with ld.bfd during your work? If so, please provide details.
The concrete problem is how much time I lose waiting for ld.

bug.short_desc: SLES 15 SP3 - kernel-default-debuginfo: cannot load kernel module debug symbols in crash tool [regression?]

long_desc.thetext:
== Comment: #0 - Steffen Maier <MAIER@de.ibm.com> - 2021-10-21 07:26:26 == Cannot debug Linux dumps for device drivers (those built as kernel modules which are many) because loading the kernel module debug symbols in crash fails with these errors:
[root@t3545002:/var/crash/2021-10-08-21:36](0)# crash vmcore vmlinux-5.3.18-59.24-default.gz ... crash> mod -s zfcp SLES 15 SP2 produces similar errors from BFD.
My last successful crash debugging session with kernel module debuginfo was on SLES 15 SP2 snapshot15 with kernel-default-5.3.18-16.2.1.s390x [in LTC bug 186966 / SUSE bug 1174318].
Did something change regarding building kernel rpms and how they post-process the kernel module .ko from the kernel build and separate debuginfo into separate .ko.debug files and rpm package?
Our s390 maintainer for binutils and gcc stated [any translation errors are mine]: <quote> For each GPR, we create a separate section with corresponding trampoline on demand. This happens for each compile unit. In order for these sections being mergeable on final link, we put them in ELF section groups. Hence, there is one section group per GPR. For a trampoline __s390_indirect_jump_rXX an ELF binary has thus a section .text.__s390_indirect_jump_rXX and the following entry in the .group section:
COMDAT group section [ 1] `.group' [__s390_indirect_jump_r14] contains 1 sections: [Index] Name [ 10] .text.__s390_indirect_jump_r14
Above error message is from binutils / BFD and is caused by a mismatch between groups in .group and the sections marked as belonging to a group.
Is it possible that this happened on extracting .ko.debug? It sounds as if the .group section is not available. </quote>
Not sure if or how related LTC bug 194414 / SUSE bug 1190743 is. It points to https://listman.redhat.com/archives/crash-utility/2021-September/msg00008.html but even without that patch I could crash manually make find and load the kernel module debuginfo and yet it still failed with the BFD errors.
OT: crash cannot load kernel module binaries which are built and packaged with xz compression [.ko.xz] since SLES 15 SP3. I could not even find .ko.xz support in upstream crash [only 2 unrelated commits both already included in SLES: support vmlinux.xz, support special crash.ko.xz]. However, I think that would not be a problem if kernel module debug info could be used instead and as super set.

Only somewhat. Of course manually uncompressing lets crash load the kernel module binary [.ko]. However, it automatically tries to load the corresponding .ko.debug, probably based on some .ko ELF information pointing to debuginfo. Loading the .ko.debug of course fails in the same way as is the reason for this bug report:

I guess, one could remove the .ko.debug so crash won't find them. Then crash would only load the .ko. But that does not seem very useful to me. We have the binary code of the loaded kernel modules in the text segments of the kernel dump anyway, I suppose.

NAME mod - module information and loading of symbols and debugging data
SYNOPSIS mod -s module [objfile] | -d module | -S [directory] [-D|-t|-r|-R|-o|-g]
DESCRIPTION With no arguments, this command displays basic information of the currently installed modules, consisting of the module address, name, size, the object file name (if known), and whether the module was compiled with CONFIG_KALLSYMS.
The arguments are concerned with with the loading or deleting of symbolic and debugging data from a module's object file. A modules's object file always contains symbolic data (symbol names and addresses), but contains debugging data only if the module was compiled with the -g CFLAG. In addition, the module may have compiled with CONFIG_KALLSYMS, which means that the module's symbolic data will have been loaded into the kernel's address space when it was installed. If the module was not compiled with CONFIG_KALLSYMS, then only the module's exported symbols will be loaded into the kernel's address space. Therefore, for the purpose of this command, it should noted that a kernel module may have been compiled in one of following manners:
1. If the module was built without CONFIG_KALLSYMS and without the -g CFLAG, then the loading of the module's additional non-exported symbols can be accomplished with this command. 2. If the module was built with CONFIG_KALLSYMS, but without the -g CFLAG, then there is no benefit in loading the symbols from the module object file, because all of the module's symbols will have been loaded into the kernel's address space when it was installed. 3. If the module was built with CONFIG_KALLSYMS and with the the -g CFLAG, then the loading of the module's debugging data can be accomplished with this command. 4. If the module was built without CONFIG_KALLSYMS but with the -g CFLAG, then the loading of the both module's symbolic and debugging data can be accomplished with this command.
-s module [objfile] Loads symbolic and debugging data from the object file for the module specified. If no objfile argument is appended, a search will be made for an object file consisting of the module name with a .o or .ko suffix, starting at the /lib/modules/<release> directory on the host system, or if not found there, starting at the directory containing the kernel namelist file. If an objfile argument is appended, then that file will be used. -d module Deletes the symbolic and debugging data of the module specified. -S [directory] Load symbolic and debugging data from the object file for all loaded modules. For each module, a search will be made for an object file consisting of the module name with a .o or .ko suffix, starting at the /lib/modules/<release> directory of the host system, or if not found there, starting at the directory containing the kernel namelist file. If a directory argument is appended, then the search will be restricted to that directory. -D Deletes the symbolic and debugging data of all modules. -t Display the contents of the module's "taints" bitmask if it is non-zero. When possible, the "taints" bits are translated to symbolic letters of the taint type; otherwise the hexadecimal value is shown. In older kernels, the contents of the "license_gplok" field is displayed in hexadecimal; the field may be either a bitmask or a boolean, depending upon the kernel version. The relevant kernel sources should be consulted for the meaning of the letter(s) or hexadecimal bit value(s). For modules that have a "gpgsig_ok" field that is zero (unsigned), the notation "(U)" is shown. -r Passes the -readnow flag to the embedded gdb module, which will override the two-stage strategy that it uses for reading symbol tables from module object files. -R Reinitialize module data. All currently-loaded symbolic and debugging data will be deleted, and the installed module list will be updated (live system only). -g When used with -s or -S, add a module object's section start and end addresses to its symbol list. -o Load module symbols with old mechanism.
If the crash session was invoked with the "--mod <directory>" option, or a CRASH_MODULE_PATH environment variable exists, then /lib/modules/<release> will be overridden as the default directory tree that is searched for module object files.
After symbolic and debugging data have been loaded, backtraces and text disassembly will be displayed appropriately. Depending upon the processor architecture, data may also printed symbolically with the "p" command; at a minimum, the "rd" command may be used with module data symbols.
If crash can recognize that the set of modules has changed while running a session on a live kernel, the module data will be reinitialized the next time this command is run; the -r option forces the reinitialization.
EXAMPLES Display the currently-installed modules:
crash> mod MODULE NAME SIZE OBJECT FILE c8019000 soundcore 2788 (not loaded) c801b000 soundlow 336 (not loaded) c801d000 sound 59864 (not loaded) c802d000 ad1848 15728 (not loaded) c8032000 uart401 6000 (not loaded) c8035000 cs4232 2472 (not loaded) c8043000 opl3 11048 (not loaded) c8047000 3c59x 18152 (not loaded) c804d000 sunrpc 53796 (not loaded) c805c000 lockd 31528 (not loaded) c8065000 nfsd 151896 (not loaded) c8092000 nfs 29752 (not loaded)

------- Comment From MAIER@de.ibm.com 2022-03-10 07:09 EDT------- Regarding the missing .group section:
(In reply to comment #0) > Our s390 maintainer for binutils and gcc stated [any translation errors are > mine]: > <quote> > Above error message is from binutils / BFD and is caused by a mismatch > between groups in .group and the sections marked as belonging to a group. > > Is it possible that this happened on extracting .ko.debug? > It sounds as if the .group section is not available. > </quote>
I received some hints from another colleague. I don't fully understand the hints but am wondering if this provides any insight for SUSE?
<quote> Even if below change has value on its own, the original problem still has to be investigated.
--- a/arch/s390/Makefile +++ b/arch/s390/Makefile @@ -83,4 +83,5 @@ ifdef CONFIG_EXPOLINE CC_FLAGS_EXPOLINE += -mfunction-return=thunk-extern else + KBUILD_LDFLAGS_MODULE += $(call ld-option, --force-group-allocation) # available since 2.29 CC_FLAGS_EXPOLINE := -mindirect-branch=thunk CC_FLAGS_EXPOLINE += -mfunction-return=thunk
From binutils ld/NEWS """ Changes in 2.29: * Section groups can now be resolved (the group deleted and the group members placed like normal sections) at partial link time either using the new linker option --force-group-allocation or by placing FORCE_GROUP_ALLOCATION into the linker script. """
Partial link is exactly the step which produces .ko from .o files during the kernel build. With that change, there are no more group sections in .ko files, expoline thunks stays in individual .text.__s390_indirect_jump_r* sections, but that should be ok.
2.29 is released 2017-07-24, not sure which version SUSE has. </quote>

Added
KBUILD_LDFLAGS_MODULE += $(call ld-option, --force-group-allocation)
to the test build at
https://download.opensuse.org/repositories/home:/michals:/kernel-test-15/pool/

I'm hoping for a re-build of the affected kernel-default-debuginfo packages once the actual root cause was fixed. Of course, that depends on some kind of reproducible build so the debuginfo package content (symbol offsets etc.) matches the (existing) kernel binary package content.
> Would IBM send the change to Linux upstream?
I don't think the kernel change was meant to be a solution for a different root cause, namely the group sections seeming to get lost when splitting debug symbols (.ko.debug) from kernel module (.ko) program code. The kernel change was just a test to see how the built kernel-default-debuginfo differs from the existing broken ones. Another Linux distribution that also splits debug symbols from kernel module program code during packaging, does not have this problem.

Please investigate lost group information when splitting debuginfo during rpm packaging.

That seems rather an error message from the crash tool. But can you provide me with the following: * a working (non-stripped) fsm.ko * a broken (rebuginfo-split) fsm.ko plus fsm.ko.debug
Perhaps I see something obvious, but it's quite possible that the crash tool would need extension in the end (e.g. by ignoring group sections in the .debug part, like it needs to ignore many other sections which are seemingly there as well, even though they don't really exist in the file, and hence are NOBITS in the .debug file).

------- Comment From MAIER@de.ibm.com 2022-04-25 12:24 EDT------- (In reply to comment #18) > In search of the root cause...
> Maybe this is related to the rpm(build) tools? > > # rpm -qf /usr/lib/rpm/find-debuginfo.sh > rpm-4.14.3-150300.46.1.s390x
More likely it's one of the "backend" tools that /usr/lib/rpm/find-debuginfo.sh invokes, such as binutils or dwz.
> Now making my own build of the same kernel to create a kernel dump and open > it in crash with the unmodified .ko intermediate build artifacts to show > that the kernel source and kernel build (and crash) work fine (but the > .ko.debug from a later rpmbuild step do not).

comment typo, I actually installed debuginfo for dwz and glibc:
# zypper install dwz-debuginfo glibc-debuginfo libelf1-debuginfo-0.168-4.5.3.s390x libz1-debuginfo-1.2.11-150000.3.30.1.s390x

(In reply to LTC BugProxy from comment #16) > ------- Comment From MAIER@de.ibm.com 2022-04-25 12:24 EDT------- > (In reply to comment #18) > > In search of the root cause... > > > Maybe this is related to the rpm(build) tools? > > > > # rpm -qf /usr/lib/rpm/find-debuginfo.sh > > rpm-4.14.3-150300.46.1.s390x > > More likely it's one of the "backend" tools that > /usr/lib/rpm/find-debuginfo.sh invokes, such as binutils or dwz.
Or of crash, not handling specific situations found in the special setup with .ko and .ko.debug files (which are somewhat strange from some p.o.v. E.g. they contain a copy of all sections headers (but not section contents) rewritten to be SHT_NOBITS, which might or might not confuse some tools).
> > dwz: dwz.c:9253: recompute_abbrevs: Assertion `off == cu_size' failed. > > /usr/lib/rpm/find-debuginfo.sh: line 569: 31302 Aborted > > (core dumped) dwz $dwz_opts ${dwz_files[@]} > > Do SUSE SLES builds also have dwz abort and dump core?
Not currently, it sometimes did in the past (but was fixed before release). But the thing is, that even if dwz dumps core the only side-effect should be that the debuginfo isn't reduced in size, or that the debuginfo isn't split away from the object files.
(dwz asserting is a bug worth reporting separately!)

------- Comment From MAIER@de.ibm.com 2022-04-25 14:15 EDT------- (In reply to comment #24) > > More likely it's one of the "backend" tools that > > /usr/lib/rpm/find-debuginfo.sh invokes, such as binutils or dwz. > > Or of crash, not handling specific situations found in the special setup > with .ko and .ko.debug files (which are somewhat strange from some p.o.v. > E.g. they contain a copy of all sections headers (but not section contents) > rewritten to be SHT_NOBITS, which might or might not confuse some tools).
(In reply to comment #18) > Another Linux distribution that also splits debug symbols from kernel module > program code during packaging, does not have this problem.
FWIW, that distro has non-empty group sections with proper entry content in .ko.debug (just like a full copy of group sections from .ko). And things just work. (It also has some PROGBITS and some RELA from .ko rewritten to NOBITS for .ko.debug).

I'll be on vacation for the next couple days, so can't look at this in more detail right now. Anyway: it was clear from the beginning that crash didn't like the specifics of how our .debug files are layed out. But some data points: as you meanwhile found out we're using binutils objcopy (from binutils) to split debuginfo from the object files (not elfutils like upstream rpm does). It doesn't really matter if you consider this coming from rpm (because it contains the find-debuginfo script) or binutils (containing the actual program doing the object file rewriting) or elfutils (containing a different program used for the same purpose by upstream rpm). At the end rpm only calls external programs to do the work, and that's where the problem is introduced.
Now we need to determine if what binutils objcopy is doing is really wrong. That eu-elflint complains about the files is not really material, because that's supposed to pedantically check for gABI/psABI compliance and the split .debug files aren't really covered by that (despite the --debuginfo flag for it, but that just means it's checking for things the elfutils project considers good debuginfo files, not what's mandated by the gABI/psABI).
Now, can somebody please attach the various artifacts involved: a full .ko file, and a split .ko/.ko.debug file as created by us, for me to take a look. Because from e.g. comment #19 it seems that eu-objcopy doesn't really split anything, as the .ko.debug file contains these section headers:
[ 5] .text PROGBITS 0000000000000000 00000080 000136f8 0 AX 0 0 8
I.e. a full .text section represented in the file itself. That's either eu-readelf following the debuginfo link or a "wrong" .debug file. And I need to determine which it is. I also need to make up my mind if the rewritten empty .group sections are wrong or acceptable in the broad design of separate debuginfo.
The thing is, the .group sections in the original .o refer to sections that aren't really part of the .debug file in the end (or rather, should not be, but should only have section headers). They could be removed, but that's not done, like for the other section headers, so that there's a one-to-one correspondence between section headers from the object file and from the debuginfo file. That together with the fact that normally final ELF files (shared libs or executables, and those don't contain groups) are split-debuginfo, not individual object files (like .ko kernel modules are), and that the kernel objects usually don't contain sections groups, except for special cases like here on s390x, make all of this fairly underspecified.
Created attachment 858450 tar archive of modules

Thanks. That all looks indeed a bit fishy, including the fact that the sections in the .ko.debug are "filled" (with zeros, but still, i.e. not NOBITS), I'll have to poke a (binutils) objcopy a bit to see what's the issue.

Okay, I think I found it, the problem is in binutils and was fixed recently (commit 7c4643efe7). At least in local tests here with the provided fsm.ko file without the patch it generates the broken fsm.ko.debug, and with it generates a sane one (it still has group sections, but the referring sections are NOBITS now, and hence ignored by libbfd).

Okay, this is good enough. That the sections are still marked 'G' in the debuginfo file causes a message but doesn't hinder it working; I think the same happened with older binutils, and can eventually be fixed in upstream binutils.
To get us unstuck I've submitted the current state as SR#272322 .
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1191908) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/272322 SLE-15-SP1 / binutils

Thanks
The MR is accepted so we can consider this fixed.
The fix is planned to be released as MU in SLE15 SP1 from which it is inherited into later service packs. In particular it is in no way related to SP4 release schedule.
There is an open question if we can massage existing .ko.debug files to be readable by crash.

bug.short_desc: File conflict in libstdc++6-pp

long_desc.thetext: File /usr/share/gdb/auto-load/usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6.0.28-gdb.py from install of libstdc++6-pp-gcc10-10.3.0+git1587-1.6.2.x86_64 (SLES12-SP5-Updates) conflicts with file from install of libstdc++6-pp-gcc9-9.2.1+r275327-1.3.9.x86_64 (SLE-Module-Toolchain12-Updates)

Duplicate of bug#1196107? That is, this should be fixed by the libstdc++6 update for gcc11 released earlier this year (installing updates should get you libstdc++6-11.[23].* which in turn will pull libstdc++6-pp-11.[23].* which should obsolete the packages with file conflicts).
So how did you get into this situation (how did you manage to install libstdc++6-pp-gcc10?)
Note with gcc12 the situation is fixed a bit better but that requires package renaming so backporting that probably isn't appropriate.

By installing gcc 10 and gcc 9 some time ago.
The zypper output suggests that these two conflicting packages come from official repositories hence the bug report.
Also for my use case I resolved the problem by zypper rm -u libstdc++6-pp-gcc9-9.2.1+r275327-1.3.9.x86_64

Hmm, odd that it removes all the other packages, they should not depend on the -pp-gccN packages.
The situation should have also resolved itself by installing the maint update that updates libstdc++6 to the gcc11 version. But maybe all the logic with supplements will confuse the solver enough to simply not install libstdc++6-pp-gcc11 ...

The gcc9 cross-compilers are not provided by SLE:
| cross-arm-gcc9 | package | 9.4.0+git2403-88.1 | x86_64 | Tools for working with the SUSE kernel sources (SLE_12_SP5)
The library they depend on is, however.

bug.short_desc: gcc with -fuse-ld=lld fails due to missing cortex flags

long_desc.thetext:
When using -fuse-ld=lld gcc fails to link on aarch64 due to a missing flag:
# gcc -fuse-ld=lld main.c ld.lld: error: unknown argument '--fix-cortex-a53-835769' collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
I think this flag needs to be silently ignored so that lld works.
Why are you using -fuse-ld=lld? Try linking with -mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > Why are you using -fuse-ld=lld?
Because lld is significantly faster than the default.
> Try linking with -mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769
gcc: error: unrecognized command-line option ‘-mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769’

(In reply to William Brown from comment #2) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > > Why are you using -fuse-ld=lld? > > Because lld is significantly faster than the default.
But lld is not supported, you are on your own when using it (with GCC even more so).
> > Try linking with -mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769 > > gcc: error: unrecognized command-line option ‘-mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769’
That's odd, it works for me (make sure to use an aarch64 compiler here!)

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #3) > (In reply to William Brown from comment #2) > > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > > > Why are you using -fuse-ld=lld? > > > > Because lld is significantly faster than the default. > > But lld is not supported, you are on your own when using it (with GCC even > more so).
gcc supplies and allows the -fuse-ld=lld argument, so I think in this case if it's present gcc should not emit incompatible flags for lld.
I am aware that lld is not supported, but my time is also important and the difference in many builds, especially rust can be more than double by swapping to lld. For further, see https://github.com/rui314/mold#readme which has other comparisons.

(In reply to William Brown from comment #4) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #3) > > (In reply to William Brown from comment #2) > > > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > > > > Why are you using -fuse-ld=lld? > > > > > > Because lld is significantly faster than the default. > > > > But lld is not supported, you are on your own when using it (with GCC even > > more so). > > gcc supplies and allows the -fuse-ld=lld argument, so I think in this case > if it's present gcc should not emit incompatible flags for lld.
GCC does not know or probe what flags lld supports if it is not configured as the default linker.
"not supported" was a statement for SUSE - lld is "supported" when used as the default linker as configured for clang/llvm, not when used with GCC.
The "proper" fix would be to make lld recognize the flag if it claims to be compatible with BFD ld, or otherwise cease supporting -fuse-ld=lld.
> I am aware that lld is not supported, but my time is also important and the > difference in many builds, especially rust can be more than double by > swapping to lld. For further, see https://github.com/rui314/mold#readme > which has other comparisons.

> > "not supported" was a statement for SUSE - lld is "supported" when used as > the default linker as configured for clang/llvm, not when used with GCC.
I'm aware of SUSE's position.
> > The "proper" fix would be to make lld recognize the flag if it claims > to be compatible with BFD ld, or otherwise cease supporting -fuse-ld=lld. >
I don't think there is any need to be so aggressive or standoff-ish about this.
Regardless, I see you've CC'ed the llvm expert, so I'm happy to work with them to help with this issue so the flag is recognised and ignored.

(In reply to William Brown from comment #0) > I think this flag needs to be silently ignored so that lld works.
Why is it being passed to the linker at all? In gcc(1):
-mfix-cortex-a53-835769 -mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769 Enable or disable the workaround for the ARM Cortex-A53 erratum number 835769. This involves inserting a NOP instruction between memory instructions and 64-bit integer multiply-accumulate instructions.
This sounds like something that only affects code generation, but indeed it's implemented in ld.bfd by patching at link time [1]. LLVM on the other hand implements the fix in code generation [2], which is likely why lld doesn't support it.
We could patch lld to ignore the flag, but then gcc+lld doesn't provide the workaround. Since Clang doesn't pass the flag (it doesn't need it), the error here is actually somewhat desirable. After all we're talking about incorrect results. We should at least warn about it.
(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #3) > > > Try linking with -mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769 > > > > gcc: error: unrecognized command-line option ‘-mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769’ > > That's odd, it works for me (make sure to use an aarch64 compiler here!)
Perhaps you could figure out why this doesn't work for you? That would be the best option.
Or of course use Clang as linker driver for lld. Not sure what you're compiling, but if it's pure Rust with the LLVM backend you could still get the fix. (Not sure if it's on by default, it seems not. Unless you're on Android. [3])
(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #5) > GCC does not know or probe what flags lld supports if it is not configured > as the default linker.
The Clang driver chooses flags at runtime, among other things depending on the linker being used. Would something similar be possible for GCC?
Of course this doesn't "scale", but it's only a small number of flags that are affected, like for LTO. [4]
> The "proper" fix would be to make lld recognize the flag if it claims > to be compatible with BFD ld, or otherwise cease supporting -fuse-ld=lld.
Since LLVM code generation already handles this in what I find a slightly more suitable place, properly handling the flag would be a hard sell.
[1] https://sourceware.org/legacy-ml/binutils/2014-10/msg00198.html [2] https://reviews.llvm.org/D5721 [3] https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/llvmorg-14.0.5/clang/lib/Driver/ToolChains/Arch/AArch64.cpp#L585-L594 [4] https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/llvmorg-14.0.5/clang/lib/Driver/ToolChains/CommonArgs.cpp#L488

(In reply to Aaron Puchert from comment #7) > Or of course use Clang as linker driver for lld. Not sure what you're > compiling, but if it's pure Rust with the LLVM backend you could still get > the fix. (Not sure if it's on by default, it seems not. Unless you're on > Android. [3])
Sorry, that's what Clang does. What Rust does depends on what kind of flags they set, but the workaround is off-by-default in the AArch64 backend [1]. It has been restructured later without changing the default [2].
[1] https://reviews.llvm.org/D5721#change-PskPjkWxaXo7 [2] https://reviews.llvm.org/D114703

long_desc.thetext:

3. Run test suites cd testsuite/ make check

[-Wimplicit-function-declaration] usleep(100); ^~~~~~ fseek Testcase compile failed, so all tests in this file will automatically fail .Running ./ltrace.torture/vfork-thread.exp ...
=== Summary ===

Below attaching the complete log

Was the process you were using before working in prior SLES 15 SP3 milestones?
Created attachment 845504 console log
Created attachment 845505 supportconfig
You did not apply the patches.

------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-01-26 07:28 EDT------- (In reply to comment #4) > Since you installed this from the ltrace-0.7.91-4.3.src, does it make a > difference if you do rpmbuild -bp ltrace.spec and build from > /usr/src/packages/BUILD directory? > I have tried with rpmbuild option... attached complete log.
> Was the process you were using before working in prior SLES 15 SP3 > milestones? We may have run this, but currently we don't have logs that I can look into previously run ltrace build log.
As part of P10 execution we need to run this ltrace source test suites, hence we have done it on SLES 15 SP3.
------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-01-26 07:30 EDT------- (In reply to comment #8) > You did not apply the patches.
----- snippet of build log where patches seems applied ----- ..... + cd ltrace-0.7.91 + /usr/bin/chmod -Rf a+rX,u+w,g-w,o-w . + echo 'Patch (readdir.patch):' Patch (readdir.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file sysdeps/linux-gnu/proc.c + echo 'Patch #2 (ltrace-fix-build.patch):' Patch #2 (ltrace-fix-build.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file testsuite/ltrace.main/filters.exp + echo 'Patch #3 (ppc-ptrace.patch):' Patch #3 (ppc-ptrace.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file sysdeps/linux-gnu/ppc/ptrace.h + echo 'Patch #4 (arm-trace.patch):' Patch #4 (arm-trace.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file sysdeps/linux-gnu/arm/trace.c + exit 0 Executing(%build): /bin/sh -e /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.8AshXb + umask 022 + cd /usr/src/packages/BUILD + /usr/bin/rm -rf /usr/src/packages/BUILDROOT/ltrace-0.7.91-4.3.ppc64le .....
Created attachment 845533 ltrace build logs

Indeed, this package does not build on SP3. It is inherited from SP0 so it probably builds there.
This is problem for Leap buildability so it should be fixed.
It is also problem because testsuite running as part of the build never runs on the current SP for inherited packages.
------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-02-08 08:46 EDT------- Any progress/updates on this?

We aren't claiming 100% clean results of testsuites included in random packages. Some of the fails are pre-existing upstream, some of them harmless, some of them due to too different (from testsuites expectation) compilation environment. In this case in particular it's due to newer glibc in SP3 that some testcases of ltrace simply can't be compiled anymore. This is no defect in ltrace itself.
It's good to track these fails for eventual analysis, but it's nothing that would hold off any release. In comparison, if you find bugs hindering actual use (by users) of any of our supported packages, that might come out different.
So, reducing severity and priority.

------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-02-10 05:28 EDT------- (In reply to comment #14) > We aren't claiming 100% clean results of testsuites included in random > packages. > Some of the fails are pre-existing upstream, some of them harmless, some of > them > due to too different (from testsuites expectation) compilation environment. > In this case in particular it's due to newer glibc in SP3 that some testcases > of ltrace simply can't be compiled anymore. This is no defect in ltrace > itself. > > It's good to track these fails for eventual analysis, but it's nothing that > would hold off any release. In comparison, if you find bugs hindering > actual use > (by users) of any of our supported packages, that might come out different. > > So, reducing severity and priority.
Agreed, will make P3.

bug.short_desc: binutils-2.37 R_X86_64_PLT32 relocation Issue

long_desc.thetext:
Oracle Eng. team needs help in understanding following:
A customer has reported an issue post upgrade to binutils-2.37.
We see a problem binutils-2.37-9.44.1 where a R_X86_64_PLT32 relocation (and a few others) is processed incorrectly.
The code in linked file points to an offset in a function or a PLT entry:
0x40052c <lxzinit+28>: callq 0x4004f1 <sltspin+4> and has an extra offset of +4. The object file has: 1c: e8 fc ff ff ff call 1d <lxzinit+0x1d> and 000000000000001d R_X86_64_PLT32 sltspin
This is an object file from an old compiler (ICC 9) which emitted addend of zero for R_X86_64_PLT32 relocation but put -4 into the instruction. The linker does not take existing -4 in the text segment into account while performing this relocation.
Can your engineering team review this please?
=====================================
Let us know what other info/log will help diagnose this.

Oh dear. Yes, there was a change in binutils that made relocation processing be more strictly conforming to the x86-64 psABI, and that specifies that relocation addends come only from the addend entry in the relocation itself, not from the relocated field (like it would on the i386 architecture, which is a REL architecture, not a RELA architecture, in the ELF sense).
The old behaviour meant that the addend could be accumulated multiple times in certain circumstances, and so that change was actually a bug fix but it indeed breaks object files which would (incorrectly) rely on that behaviour. Unfortunately I don't see a way how to do both: accept that object file and have the bug fixed.
CCing Jan, the author, perhaps he has an idea. We might have to declare such object files broken and hence unsupported. The only current work around I see is to no update binutils on the affected system :-(
(FWIW, it's 17c6c3b99156fe82c1e637e1a5fd9f163ac788c8 in upstream binutils which was the change).

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #1) > CCing Jan, the author, perhaps he has an idea.
Well, I'm very hesitant to suggest to try to invent some workaround. It would likely be possible, as PLT32 with an addend of other than -4 is likely wrong anyway, and finding -4 in the relocated field could be taken as "justification" to convert that into an addend.
If anything I'd be more inclined (but only slightly) to invent a new objcopy option to allow to convert such files into well-formed ones. But obviously this would still require changes to their build system.
> We might have to declare such object files broken and hence unsupported.
There's nothing to "declare" in the sense of the word - they are broken if the relocation entry is a RELA one and the addend in that entry isn't -4. What's in the .text section bytes is of no interest. And I don't think we have ever claimed to support (all kinds of) broken object files.
> The only current work around I see is > to no update binutils on the affected system :-(
Indeed. Or fix the malformed object files.

(In reply to Jan Beulich from comment #2) > > We might have to declare such object files broken and hence unsupported. > > There's nothing to "declare" in the sense of the word - they are broken if > the relocation entry is a RELA one and the addend in that entry isn't -4.
"broken" has many different meanings, depending on context. In this case a customer could justifiably claim that the old object files weren't broken, as clearly they worked before, no matter what a standard said. And in that sense we, as the supporting entity, also need to explicitely say: unsupported, based on a conscious decision; a declaration of facts, if you wish.
But that's splitting hairs :-)
> What's in the .text section bytes is of no interest. And I don't think we > have ever claimed to support (all kinds of) broken object files.
Of course not. But on a best effort basis things aren't black and white. As I said, we can decide to INVALID this one if all work-arounds just look worse.
> > The only current work around I see is > > to no update binutils on the affected system :-( > > Indeed. Or fix the malformed object files.

(In reply to Jan Beulich from comment #2) > > The only current work around I see is > > to no update binutils on the affected system :-( > > Indeed. Or fix the malformed object files.
Yeah, I thought so as well. So, Arun, would Oracle be okay with the object files being fixed manually? Can they do that themself, or do they need help in that? We're unlikely to change binutils to accept these object files as-is.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #4) > (In reply to Jan Beulich from comment #2) > > > The only current work around I see is > > > to no update binutils on the affected system :-( > > > > Indeed. Or fix the malformed object files. > > Yeah, I thought so as well. So, Arun, would Oracle be okay with the object > files being fixed manually? Can they do that themself, or do they need help > in that? > We're unlikely to change binutils to accept these object files as-is.
I can check with them, Please outline what steps needed to achieve this.

(In reply to Arun Singh from comment #5) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #4) > > (In reply to Jan Beulich from comment #2) > > > > The only current work around I see is > > > > to no update binutils on the affected system :-( > > > > > > Indeed. Or fix the malformed object files. > > > > Yeah, I thought so as well. So, Arun, would Oracle be okay with the object > > files being fixed manually? Can they do that themself, or do they need help > > in that? > > We're unlikely to change binutils to accept these object files as-is. > > I can check with them, Please outline what steps needed to achieve this.
Here is response from Oracle Eng.
From: Eugene Karichkin <Eugene.Karichkin@oracle.com> Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2022 10:07 AM
Subject: Re: [External] : RE: Issue on SLES12 SP5 with binutils-2.37
Arun,
I don't think it is feasible for us to to fix object files. Such files are already in the field and we still have them produced when we support old releases. Our customers who upgrade binutils will be unable to patch a number of Oracle products. We need the old ld behavior by default.
Thanks.

(In reply to Arun Singh from comment #6) > (In reply to Arun Singh from comment #5) > > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #4) > > > (In reply to Jan Beulich from comment #2) > > > > > The only current work around I see is > > > > > to no update binutils on the affected system :-( > > > > > > > > Indeed. Or fix the malformed object files. > > > > > > Yeah, I thought so as well. So, Arun, would Oracle be okay with the object > > > files being fixed manually? Can they do that themself, or do they need help > > > in that? > > > We're unlikely to change binutils to accept these object files as-is. > > > > I can check with them, Please outline what steps needed to achieve this. > > Here is response from Oracle Eng. > > From: Eugene Karichkin <Eugene.Karichkin@oracle.com> > Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2022 10:07 AM > > Subject: Re: [External] : RE: Issue on SLES12 SP5 with binutils-2.37 > > Arun, > > I don't think it is feasible for us to to fix object files. Such files are > already in the field and we still have them produced when we support old > releases. Our customers who upgrade binutils will be unable to patch a > number of Oracle products. We need the old ld behavior by default. > > Thanks.
Michael & Jan - If you want to chat with Eugene, please feel free to ping directly.

(In reply to Arun Singh from comment #6) > (In reply to Arun Singh from comment #5) > > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #4) > > > (In reply to Jan Beulich from comment #2) > > > > > The only current work around I see is > > > > > to no update binutils on the affected system :-( > > > > > > > > Indeed. Or fix the malformed object files. > > > > > > Yeah, I thought so as well. So, Arun, would Oracle be okay with the object > > > files being fixed manually? Can they do that themself, or do they need help > > > in that? > > > We're unlikely to change binutils to accept these object files as-is. > > > > I can check with them, Please outline what steps needed to achieve this. > > Here is response from Oracle Eng. > > From: Eugene Karichkin <Eugene.Karichkin@oracle.com> > Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2022 10:07 AM > > Subject: Re: [External] : RE: Issue on SLES12 SP5 with binutils-2.37 > > Arun, > > I don't think it is feasible for us to to fix object files. Such files are > already in the field and we still have them produced when we support old > releases. Our customers who upgrade binutils will be unable to patch a > number of Oracle products. We need the old ld behavior by default. > > Thanks.
Michael & Jan -
Can you please look into restoring requested old behavior? This is critical for SUSE/Oracle customers & holding them from upgrading to SLES12 SP5. Thx!

Since as far as I can see the upstream change was not in response to an actual problem in the field (which would be garbage-in, garbage-out) it seems reasonable to revert the behavior for SLES for the sake of bug-compatibility since we now do run into an issue in the field.
Yeah, I think that's the route I'll take.

Question from Oracle Support 9via Oracle Eng.):
> The customer is asking for a workaround. How do they get past the > issue if they have already upgraded to binutils 2.37
Also as a note, Oracle is not seeing this issue in their Linux due to older binutils version: In OL8 we ship binutils 2.30. In OL9-beta we ship binutils 2.35.

(In reply to Arun Singh from comment #11) > Question from Oracle Support 9via Oracle Eng.): > > > The customer is asking for a workaround. How do they get past the > > issue if they have already upgraded to binutils 2.37 > > > Also as a note, Oracle is not seeing this issue in their Linux due to older > binutils version: In OL8 we ship binutils 2.30. In OL9-beta we ship > binutils 2.35.
Yep, the first release with the change was 2.37.

SR#270892 for SLE-12. I wonder if we want this for SLE-15 as well, if possible I would like to stay with upstream behaviour as much as possible, even if that means a divergence between SLE-12 and SLE-15. But if this same problem also exists on the SLE-15 variant of e.g. Oracle then we should include this reversion there as well.
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1198422) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/270892 SLE-12 / binutils

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #13) > SR#270892 for SLE-12. I wonder if we want this for SLE-15 as well, if > possible > I would like to stay with upstream behaviour as much as possible, even if > that > means a divergence between SLE-12 and SLE-15. But if this same problem also > exists on the SLE-15 variant of e.g. Oracle then we should include this > reversion > there as well.
Thanks Michael for getting this done for SLE-12. We haven't received push for SLE-15, it may change in future. We are good for now.

(In reply to Arun Singh from comment #15)
> Thanks Michael for getting this done for SLE-12. We haven't received push > for SLE-15, it may change in future. We are good for now.
Sorry Michael, I spoke too soon.
Now, they have escalated for SLE-15 fix as well. Oracle Team impacted by this is EBS which is supported on SLE-12 & we are pushing to get SLE-15 supported (for obvious reasons). We should not give them any excuse to not support SLE-15.
Please consider implementing this fix for SLE-15 as well. Thanks!
No problem, I'm preparing it in Devel:Toolchain:SLE15, and will submit as maint update if that works out fine.
SR#271687 it is now, for SLE-15-SP1:Update.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #18) > SR#271687 it is now, for SLE-15-SP1:Update.
Thanks Michael. Very helpful!

The first time we got problems with the Oracle EBS cloning procedure was in December 2021, I can’t remember the exact date.

Whatever problem that customer has, it's not related to this specific bug report here. The PLT32 relocation handling changed at the version update to 2.37, not at the above minor change.
