(plus:DI (reg/f:DI 29 x29) [ 136s] (const_int 184 [0xb8])) [0 %sfp+-456 S8 A64]) [ 136s] (reg:DI 32 v0)) /usr/include/bits/stdio2.h:97 33 {*movdi_aarch64} [ 136s] (nil)) [ 136s] spring_electrical.c:2111:1: internal compiler error: in reload_cse_simplify_operands, at postreload.c:411
Seems reproducible. I don't think anyone seriously uses the binary on arm but other packages may be affected.

SLE-12 gcc 4.8 on aarch64 is very brittle, it's the first version of that backend and came very late, one could call it technical preview (one can argue if it's a good idea to use that for an enterprise distro). One side-effect is problems like this, when compiling much newer software. If you want to build graphviz on aarch64, then use the one from SLE-12-SP2:Update, not the one from openSUSE:Factory, like currently is the case with Kernel:Tools.
You might also try to remove any of these compile flags: -fstack-protector -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fstack-clash-protection the internal error is related to a stack spill store of a vector register in DI mode, so it might also be that removal of -ffast-math helps. It's unlikely that we will (if even possible) fix this problem in the gcc48 compiler at this time.
Low prio, as no SLE package is affected.

Neither removing -ffast-math nor removing the stack protector flags fixes the problem.
The repository is built for aarch64 because some of the tools might be of use on all architectures but I don't expect graphviz to be one of them.
The version of graphviz from SLE-12-SP2:Update is not useful, that's the whole point of building it in this repository.

(In reply to Michal Suchanek from comment #2) > Neither removing -ffast-math nor removing the stack protector flags fixes > the problem.
Okay.
> The repository is built for aarch64 because some of the tools might be of > use on all architectures but I don't expect graphviz to be one of them. > > The version of graphviz from SLE-12-SP2:Update is not useful, that's the > whole point of building it in this repository.
I see, then we'll have to live with this for the time being.
You can also use for example GCC 7 to compile things which is available from the Toolchain module (and is the supported SLE15 system compiler).

Thanks for the suggestion.
That sounds like viable workaround for compiling out-of-distro package updates that don't build with the default compiler.

bug.short_desc: gcc-ada built with incorrect target

long_desc.thetext:
The gcc compiler suit, such as the c & c++ compilers, have a target set to x86_64-suse-linux.
The gcc-ada build however, thinks that the target is x86_64-suse-linux-gnu, as can be seen from: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/adainclude/s-oscons.ads: Target_Name : constant String := "x86_64-suse-linux-gnu";
In other words, there is a mismatch.
This royally mucks up the building of gprbuild since the path is set to /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux, not /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux-gnu.
This is the same with v10 & v11 compilers, on both x86_64 & aarch64, as well as 15.3 and tumbleweed.
We cannot modify /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/adainclude/s-oscons.ads, since we would be required to rebuild the GNAT runtime library.
Indeed, from /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/11/adainclude/s-oscons.ads, it states: -- This file is generated automatically, do not modify it by hand! Instead, -- make changes to s-oscons-tmplt.c and rebuild the GNAT runtime library. -- This is the version for x86_64-suse-linux-gnu
While this may not be a big deal from folks used to c & c++, this is a massive problem for those wanting to use Ada, espacially where Ada software requires the gprbuild tools to be built.
If this can be fixed, then it means the AdaCore tools can be easily comiled and installed.

Isn't this the fault of the gprbuild tools? We configure like
../configure --prefix=/usr --infodir=/usr/share/info --mandir=/usr/share/man --libdir=/usr/lib64 --libexecdir=/usr/lib64 --enable-languages=c,c++,objc,fortran,obj-c++,ada,go --enable-offload-targets=hsa,nvptx-none, --without-cuda-driver --enable-checking=release --disable-werror --with-gxx-include-dir=/usr/include/c++/7 --enable-ssp --disable-libssp --disable-libvtv --disable-libcc1 --enable-plugin --with-bugurl=https://bugs.opensuse.org/ '--with-pkgversion=SUSE Linux' --with-slibdir=/lib64 --with-system-zlib --enable-libstdcxx-allocator=new --disable-libstdcxx-pch --enable-version-specific-runtime-libs --with-gcc-major-version-only --enable-linker-build-id --enable-linux-futex --enable-gnu-indirect-function --program-suffix=-7 --without-system-libunwind --enable-multilib --with-arch-32=x86-64 --with-tune=generic --build=x86_64-suse-linux --host=x86_64-suse-linux
resulting in
checking build system type... x86_64-suse-linux-gnu checking host system type... x86_64-suse-linux-gnu checking target system type... x86_64-suse-linux-gnu
how do the gprbuild tools figure the path to use? Btw, the same "issue" is present with binutils resulting in a /usr/x86_64-suse-linux/ path.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > Isn't this the fault of the gprbuild tools? We configure like > > ../configure --prefix=/usr --infodir=/usr/share/info --mandir=/usr/share/man > --libdir=/usr/lib64 --libexecdir=/usr/lib64 > --enable-languages=c,c++,objc,fortran,obj-c++,ada,go > --enable-offload-targets=hsa,nvptx-none, --without-cuda-driver > --enable-checking=release --disable-werror > --with-gxx-include-dir=/usr/include/c++/7 --enable-ssp --disable-libssp > --disable-libvtv --disable-libcc1 --enable-plugin > --with-bugurl=https://bugs.opensuse.org/ '--with-pkgversion=SUSE Linux' > --with-slibdir=/lib64 --with-system-zlib --enable-libstdcxx-allocator=new > --disable-libstdcxx-pch --enable-version-specific-runtime-libs > --with-gcc-major-version-only --enable-linker-build-id --enable-linux-futex > --enable-gnu-indirect-function --program-suffix=-7 > --without-system-libunwind --enable-multilib --with-arch-32=x86-64 > --with-tune=generic --build=x86_64-suse-linux --host=x86_64-suse-linux > > resulting in > > checking build system type... x86_64-suse-linux-gnu > checking host system type... x86_64-suse-linux-gnu > checking target system type... x86_64-suse-linux-gnu > > how do the gprbuild tools figure the path to use? Btw, the same "issue" > is present with binutils resulting in a /usr/x86_64-suse-linux/ path.
Except that: eth5:~$ gcc -dumpmachine x86_64-suse-linux
So x86_64-suse-linux != x86_64-suse-linux-gnu
As for how gprbuild figures this out... don't ask, it's a mess. However it looks at the output of -dumpmachine and compares it to TARGET in /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/adainclude/s-oscons.ads and sees that they are different and barfs.
I can help feeling that both --build and--host should be set to x86_64-suse-linux-gnu, but I think that would just break other things. Can't help feeling this is a problem in the initial source.

Hmpf, so the directory name and the -dumpmachine output is using the configured target, while s-oscons.ads contains the canonicalized variant. Gah!
Quick grepping on our binary packages indicates that that's the _only_ place where the canonical name is used, so maybe the best course of action would be to hack on it long enough that the generated s-oscons.ads also just contains the provided name without canonicalization.

Note gcc -v also prints
Target: x86_64-suse-linux
a more reliable way to construct the path is to use sth like
gcc -print-file-name=cc1
which results in
/usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/cc1
and which can be used as base to derive whatever actual path gprbuild tools want to figure out.
Btw, s-oscons.ads is built by the
./bldtools/oscons/xoscons: xoscons.adb xutil.ads xutil.adb -$(MKDIR) ./bldtools/oscons $(RM) $(addprefix ./bldtools/oscons/,$(notdir $^)) $(CP) $^ ./bldtools/oscons (cd ./bldtools/oscons ; gnatmake -q xoscons)
$(RTSDIR)/s-oscons.ads: ../stamp-gnatlib1-$(RTSDIR) s-oscons-tmplt.c gsocket.h ./bldtools/oscons/xoscons $(RM) $(RTSDIR)/s-oscons-tmplt.i $(RTSDIR)/s-oscons-tmplt.s (cd $(RTSDIR) ; \ $(OSCONS_CPP) ; \ $(OSCONS_EXTRACT) ; \ ../bldtools/oscons/xoscons s-oscons)
tools. It seems the actual name is passed via
OSCONS_CPP=$(OSCONS_CC) $(GNATLIBCFLAGS_FOR_C) -E -C \ -DTARGET=\"$(target)\" -iquote $(fsrcpfx)ada $(fsrcpfx)ada/s-oscons-tmplt.c > s-oscons-tmplt.i
but the paths on the filesystem will end up using target_noncanonical (which isn't available in this makefile).
The following should eventually fix that but then I don't know whether that has consequences downstream on how gnat functions. Maybe you can manually edit s-oscons.adb in your install and see whether it breaks anything since you seem to be set up to do some actual testing on whether gnat functions?
It seems we do not provide packages for gprbuild (googling finds it on github), but there are attempts to do so in some home:$USER:devel:languages:Ada projects.
diff --git a/gcc/ada/gcc-interface/Makefile.in b/gcc/ada/gcc-interface/Makefile.in index b8a24708280..1e9801a8b96 100644 --- a/gcc/ada/gcc-interface/Makefile.in +++ b/gcc/ada/gcc-interface/Makefile.in @@ -138,6 +138,7 @@ objdir = .
target_alias=@target_alias@ target=@target@ +target_noncanonical=@target_noncanonical@ target_cpu=@target_cpu@ target_vendor=@target_vendor@ target_os=@target_os@ @@ -598,7 +599,7 @@ OSCONS_CC=$(subst ./xgcc,../../xgcc,$(subst -B./, -B../../,$(GCC_FOR_TARGET))) # has a <types.h> header).
OSCONS_CPP=$(OSCONS_CC) $(GNATLIBCFLAGS_FOR_C) -E -C \ - -DTARGET=\"$(target)\" -iquote $(fsrcpfx)ada $(fsrcpfx)ada/s-oscons-tmplt.c > s-oscons-tmplt.i + -DTARGET=\"$(target_noncanonical)\" -iquote $(fsrcpfx)ada $(fsrcpfx)ada/s-oscons-tmplt.c > s-oscons-tmplt.i OSCONS_EXTRACT=$(OSCONS_CC) $(GNATLIBCFLAGS_FOR_C) -S s-oscons-tmplt.i
# Note: if you need to build with a non-GNU compiler, you could adapt the
I filed an upstream issue, let's see. Maybe you can file an issue on the gprbuild side as well.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #5) > I filed an upstream issue, let's see. Maybe you can file an issue on the > gprbuild side as well.
I too filed an issue: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=104856
I assume yours is: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=104861
Sorry, I should have said. At least though I do seem to have found a bug rather that just my usual config error.
I'm hoping the fix will be ported to v7 though since this is still rather current.

Superb, a quick fix to tell comilers.xml that the libraries are in lib64, I've build gcc, gprbuild & xmlada all without major issue. Only think I have do was symlink libgcc_s.so so it could be found by the linker. Excelent work guys.
Now the next question. When will the next release incorporating this fix be released? Any hint at all will be welcome.

(In reply to Bob Goddard from comment #7) > Superb, a quick fix to tell comilers.xml that the libraries are in lib64, > I've build gcc, gprbuild & xmlada all without major issue. Only think I have > do was symlink libgcc_s.so so it could be found by the linker. Excelent work > guys. > > Now the next question. When will the next release incorporating this fix be > released? Any hint at all will be welcome.
I've put the fix into devel:gcc/gcc7 which means its queued for the next update reaching SLES and openSUSE Leap - there's not yet any ETA for that though. It would help if you can verify the build packages in devel:gcc/gcc7 for Leap work for the issue at hand (builds are still running though).
The fix will reach openSUSE Tumbleweed as well via updates from upstream, I will probably push it there at the beginning of next week.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #8) > (In reply to Bob Goddard from comment #7) > > Superb, a quick fix to tell comilers.xml that the libraries are in lib64, > > I've build gcc, gprbuild & xmlada all without major issue. Only think I have > > do was symlink libgcc_s.so so it could be found by the linker. Excelent work > > guys. > > > > Now the next question. Hmmm, I also installed gcc7-ada-7.5.0+r278197-lp153.208.1.x86_64, which appears to be the correct one.
I think things just got a litle mixed up. I've checked /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/adainclude/s-oscons.ads and /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/11/adainclude/s-oscons.ads, and the '7' version is correct, '11' is still wrong.
So I think the links were still installed from gcc-7 to gcc and thus picked up the correct compiler.

Ugh...
I had multiple installs of gcc, including that which I build myself.
As a separate issue, gcc7 is now too old to build gprbuild. The patch though is still correct.

bug.short_desc: UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d, 0x33, 0x18, 0xb7, 0x8c, 0xdb) not considered constant

long_desc.thetext:
static const uuid_le uuid_pmem = UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d, 0x33, 0x18, 0xb7, 0x8c, 0xdb);
does not compile:
[ 56s] ../acpi.h:20:1: error: initializer element is not constant [ 56s] static const uuid_le uuid_pmem = UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d,
https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/home:michals/ndctl/SLE_12_SP5/x86_64
note: this package is not needed in 12 SP5
however, uuid in particular and similar constructs in general are common so other packages may hit this issue

Created attachment 842855 preprocessed source of the failing file
gcc -std=gnu99 -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I.. -include ../config.h -DSYSCONFDIR=\""/etc"\" -DLIBEXECDIR=\""/usr/lib"\" -DPREFIX=\""/usr"\" -DNDCTL_MAN_PATH=\""/usr/share/man"\" -I../ndctl/lib -I../ndctl -I../ -I/usr/include/kmod -I/usr/include/uuid -I/usr/include/json-c -Wall -Wchar-subscripts -Wformat-security -Wmissing-declarations -Wmissing-prototypes -Wnested-externs -Wshadow -Wsign-compare -Wstrict-prototypes -Wtype-limits -Wmaybe-uninitialized -Wdeclaration-after-statement -Wunused-result -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -O2 -fvisibility=hidden -ffunction-sections -fdata-sections -fmessage-length=0 -grecord-gcc-switches -fstack-protector -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -g -c -o create-nfit.o create-nfit.c In file included from create-nfit.c:25:0: ../acpi.h:20:1: error: initializer element is not constant static const uuid_le uuid_pmem = UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d, ^
GCC 5 is the first non-affected release.

Fixed with r5-4232-g7278465e24b3d5a3:
re PR c/63567 (Linux kernel build error due to non-static initializers)
PR c/63567 * c-typeck.c (digest_init): Allow initializing objects with static storage duration with compound literals even in C99 and add pedwarn for it.
* gcc.dg/pr61096-1.c: Change dg-error into dg-warning. * gcc.dg/pr63567-1.c: New test. * gcc.dg/pr63567-2.c: New test.
From-SVN: r216416

Indeed.
> gcc-10 -S t.c -std=c99 -O2 -pedantic-errors t.c:4:35: error: initializer element is not constant [-Wpedantic] 4 | static const uuid_le uuid_pmem2 = (uuid_le){{ 0x0 }}; | ^
but fine without the (uuid_le) so it seems not using a compound literal but an initializer would be more standard conforming here.
Let me backport this to devel:gcc/gcc48 to be picked up in case we ever do another update for SLE12

bug.short_desc: ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 2.32.0.20190909-6.8 internal error, aborting at ../../bfd/bfd.c:1078 in _bfd_doprnt_scan

long_desc.thetext: The devel:gcc gdb package runs the testsuite for sle-15 s390 -m31, and we run into: ... gnatlink foo.ali -m31 -g -O2 -o /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-10.0.50.20200806/build-s390x-suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m31/outputs/gdb.ada/O2_float_param/foo^M /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 2.32.0.20190909-6.8 internal error, aborting at ../../bfd/bfd.c:1078 in _bfd_doprnt_scan^M ^M /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: Please report this bug.^M ^M collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status^M gnatlink: error when calling /usr/bin/gcc^M gnatmake: *** link failed.^M compiler exited with status 1 ...
Hmm, I'm not sure I want to investigate this one as the binutils update to 2.35 will come soon. I'll try reproducing first.

Okay, still happens with 2.35 as well, from ibs://home:matz2:sle15sp2/gdb:testsuite, gdb-s390x-suse-linux-m31.log :
gnatlink foo.ali -m31 -g -O2 -o /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-9.2/build-s390x- suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m31/outputs/gdb.ada/O2_float_param/foo /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; home:matz2:sle15sp2) 2.35 internal error, aborting at ../../bfd/bfd.c: 1307 in _bfd_doprnt_scan
/usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: Please re port this bug.
So, confirmed, but not urgent, as SLE15 doesn't need s390 (m31) extensively. For after my vacation.

bug.short_desc: FTBFS: llvm5 won't compile on SP4

long_desc.thetext:
I test compiled all sources appearing on SP4 Full ISO within IBS. And llvm5 failed to build there.
Please see https://build.suse.de/package/show/home:coolo:rebuild-sp4/llvm5
FYI: The binary packages found on the SP4 medium are: libomp5-devel, llvm5-devel, llvm5-gold, clang5-devel, clang5, libLTO5, libclang5, libLLVM5, llvm5-LTO-devel, llvm5, clang5-checker, libLLVM5-32bit

[ 891s] ../projects/compiler-rt/lib/sanitizer_common/sanitizer_platform_limits_ posix.cc:162:10: fatal error: 'sys/ustat.h' file not found [ 891s] #include <sys/ustat.h> [ 891s] ^~~~~~~~~~~~~ [ 891s] 1 error generated.
no idea. But then llvm5 should be obsoleted by llvm7 in SP1 - ideally _all_ packages from llvm5 would be blocked from the media.
Any info on what actually depends on the subset of subpackages that _are_ on the media?
clang5-devel was moved from devel tools to legacy for SP4 - looks like it was still in devel tools in SP3. If it could be dropped as well I can't tell

bug.short_desc: [Migration][Build 34.1] openQA test fails in patch_sle - binutils-devel-2.31-9.29.1.aarch64 requires binutils = 2.31-9.29.1

long_desc.thetext:
## Observation
While migrated from sles12sp3 ltss to sles15sp5 we hit this kind of conflict at the patch_sle step. ------------------------------ Processing conflicts - 0 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <3> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(solving):610 Solverrun finished with an ERROR 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <2> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(resolvePool):774 SATResolver::resolvePool() done. Ret:0 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] Resolver.cc(problems):383 Resolver::problems() 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1138 Encountered problems! Here are the solutions: 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1138 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1142 Problem 1: 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1143 ==================================== 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1147 binutils-devel-2.31-9.29.1.aarch64 requires binutils = 2.31-9.29.1, but this requirement cannot be provided 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1148 ------------------------------------ 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [libsolv++] PoolImpl.cc(logSat):119 solver statistics: 0 learned rules, 2 unsolvable, 0 minimization steps EOL --------------------------------------------
openQA test in scenario sle-15-SP3-Migration-from-SLE12-SPx-aarch64-offline_sles12sp3_ltss_pscc_sdk_all_full_lock@aarch64 fails in [patch_sle](https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/4699416/modules/patch_sle/steps/67)
## Test suite description The base test suite is used for job templates defined in YAML documents. It has no settings of its own.
## Reproducible
Fails since (at least) Build [33.1](https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/4687844)
## Expected result
Last good: (unknown) (or more recent)
## Further details
Always latest result in this scenario: [latest](https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/latest?arch=aarch64&distri=sle&flavor=Migration-from-SLE12-SPx&machine=aarch64&test=offline_sles12sp3_ltss_pscc_sdk_all_full_lock&version=15-SP3)

We hit this issue again but this time it got zypper log. so I uploaded the zypper log for more information. thanks
https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/4712868
Created attachment 841819 zypper log
Created attachment 841820 patch_sle-y2logs
Created attachment 841831 Test Solver part1
Created attachment 841832 test solver part2
I've uploaded the test solver log, you can merge them with cat patch_sle-solverTestCase* > patch_sle-solverTestCase.tar.bz2
Stefan, could you please check if this needs to be fixed on the 15-SP3 side?

FWIW; I added binutils-devel to the 12-sp3-ltss channel meta, but we have not yet released an update for it. (actually I am expecting a toolchain binutils update in the next weeks.)
So this is a case where SERVER 12-sp3 + SERVER-LTSS 12-sp3 + SDK 12-sp3 is used in transition, but SLES 12 Sp3 LTSS does not have the -devel pacakge yet.
(There are more reports like this, where SERVER + LTSS + SDK tries to get migrated, but actually show reports of SDK+LTSS problems in SLE12).

bug.short_desc: Semantic interposition inhibits optimization of shared libraries

long_desc.thetext:
By default, any visible symbol in shared libraries (PIC) can be overwritten during runtime by the executable or mechanisms such as LD_PRELOAD, this is called semantic interposition.
This however affects optimization of shared libraries quite badly, because any call or reference to exported functions (or symbols in general) in the same library might not actually resolve to the symbol in that library anymore. Any such references have to be resolved during runtime (GOT+PLT relocations) and interprocedural optimization is not possible anymore.
For executables (also PIE) this is not the case, they can utilize direct calls and references to global data. Through the magic of copy relocations, it can even reference global data from shared objects directly. Libraries then use the copy of the global data from the executable instead of their own.
As libraries actually make up the most code on the system, optimizing for those is actually worthwhile. Using the "-fno-semantic-interposition" compiler option, interprocedural optimization can be enabled for exported symbols and the linker option "-Bsymbolic(-functions)" allows symbol references inside the same object to be resolved directly instead of going through runtime relocation.
Some libraries enable those options themselves already like openssl. Qt also used "-Bsymbolic" for a long time, but it conflicted with the "gcc-PIE" package which built incompatible executables and so it got disabled again (boo#1175278).
However, executables have to be built with that in mind (by compiling them like PIC) to avoid features which rely on interposition, like copy relocations. The "-fno-direct-access-external-data" option achieves that FWICT.
It would be great if we could build (most parts of) the distro such that libraries can be optimized more.
Thread on the GCC ML about -fno-semantic-interposition: https://gcc.gnu.org/pipermail/gcc-patches/2021-June/572018.html GCC PR report about -fno-direct-access-external-data: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=98112 Extensive discussion about Qt's reduce-relocations option: https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-86173 Blog posts about this topic: https://maskray.me/blog/2021-05-09-fno-semantic-interposition https://maskray.me/blog/2021-05-16-elf-interposition-and-bsymbolic

(In reply to Fabian Vogt from comment #0) > Using the "-fno-semantic-interposition" compiler option, interprocedural > optimization can be enabled for exported symbols [...] The way I see it, -fno-semantic-interposition is justified by the "one definition rule" in both C and C++. Having different functions with the same (qualified) name (and signature for C++) is not allowed in a program. There is still a non-standard "back door": __attribute__((weak)). So if necessary it's still possible to define overridable functions, but other libraries can't just override anything they want. It's also kind of on-by-default in Clang (not literally, but Clang does IPO on default visibility functions) and on other platforms, so there is hopefully not a lot of software out there that relies on semantic interposition.
> [...] and the linker option "-Bsymbolic(-functions)" allows symbol > references inside the same object to be resolved directly instead of going > through runtime relocation. [...] > > However, executables have to be built with that in mind (by compiling them > like PIC) to avoid features which rely on interposition, like copy > relocations. The "-fno-direct-access-external-data" option achieves that > FWICT. In the thread where Fangrui Song aka maskray proposed to enable these flags for building Clang [1], the time difference between -Bsymbolic and -Bsymbolic-functions was minor. For Qt it might very well look different though.
Address uniqueness is probably not a big issue, but it certainly can be an issue, as the standards guarantee it. So I think we could enable -Bsymbolic-functions on a per-package basis, but probably not globally. Avoiding copy relocations for -Bsymbolic might be too high a price to pay, at least in general. I don't know how common default visibility variables are, and whether they're typically used more often by the library or the program. With modern libraries I'd expect there not be a lot of exported variables, so maybe it just doesn't matter that much.
So I'd be in favor of enabling -fno-semantic-interposition by default, but not -Bsymbolic[-functions]. We can enable that where it matters and where we think it's safe.
I played with -Bsymbolic in the LLVM build once, but I'm mostly compiling C++ where the compile jobs take so long that the initial relocation processing doesn't change much. (Since we're building LLVM with Clang, we already have IPO for default visibility functions.)
[1] https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/20210501235549.vugtjeb7dmd5xell@google.com/

(In reply to Aaron Puchert from comment #1) > (In reply to Fabian Vogt from comment #0) > > Using the "-fno-semantic-interposition" compiler option, interprocedural > > optimization can be enabled for exported symbols [...] > The way I see it, -fno-semantic-interposition is justified by the "one > definition rule" in both C and C++. Having different functions with the same > (qualified) name (and signature for C++) is not allowed in a program. There > is still a non-standard "back door": __attribute__((weak)). So if necessary > it's still possible to define overridable functions, but other libraries > can't just override anything they want. It's also kind of on-by-default in > Clang (not literally, but Clang does IPO on default visibility functions) > and on other platforms, so there is hopefully not a lot of software out > there that relies on semantic interposition.
I think for GCC the ODR trumps -fsemantic-interposition though GCC applies ODR only to C++. Honza, please correct me if I'm wrong here. So I'm not sure whether -fno-semantic-interposition on its own has any measurable effect on a C++ code base.
For C there's no ODR so things are more complicated.

As I wrote to maskray on the generic-abi list ( https://groups.google.com/g/generic-abi/c/LgSC6te51uM/m/WGzfjtFKAgAJ ) I'm quite heavily opposed to disabling interposition wholesale. I would perhaps support it when restricted to C++ symbols for functions.
Also note that protected visiblity is going to be fixed on x86-64 (to not be worse than default visibility and break with copy relocations, i.e. it will work again like before 2014/15) over the next months. At that point packages choosing so can simply use that.
-Bsymbolic should be regarded as a hack in the ELF world, because ELF has symbol visibility which is (or was, and will be again) designed to be exactly that. And of course the compiler doesn't know anything about it, so can't base it's inlining decisions on it. (Which is the whole reason why people had to invent still another flag for the compiler; well, that and because protected visibility wasn't working as designed/desired).
So, my course of action would be: wait for protected symbol visibility to be fixed again, make it so that packages can select that visibility as default for C++ functions (select it in a way the compiler knows), let packages decide. Possibly make that default in the toolchain after quite some time.

Note that for instance in above generic-abi thread maskray says that most speedup for clang itself was by avoiding the symbolic relocations, i.e. what protected visibility or variants of -Bsymbolic* give you, _not_ what -fno-semantic-interposition gives you. There are unclear claims about fantastic speedups with cpython, which look a bit doubtful or are done on unrealistic microbenchmarks, that may or may not come from the disabled interposition or from reduced relocations.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #2) > For C there's no ODR so things are more complicated. What about C11 6.9.5?
An external definition is an external declaration that is also a definition of a function (other than an inline definition) or an object. If an identifier declared with external linkage is used in an expression (other than as part of the operand of a sizeof or _Alignof operator whose result is an integer constant), somewhere in the entire program there shall be exactly one external definition for the identifier; otherwise, there shall be no more than one.
(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #3) > I'm quite heavily opposed to disabling interposition wholesale. In my view this is more about explicitly annotating interposable functions as weak instead of allowing interposition for any function.
ELF default visibility has always implied interposability, but I think that's mostly seen as historical artifact by now. Visibility and interposability are pretty much orthogonal. Just because a library is "exporting" functions doesn't mean it's inviting others to replace them. With a few exceptions that makes absolutely no sense, and it wouldn't hurt to mark these exceptions as "weak".
> Also note that protected visiblity is going to be fixed on x86-64 (to not be > worse than default visibility and break with copy relocations, i.e. it will > work again like before 2014/15) over the next months. What are the ideas for that? Not doing copy relocations at all, or giving protected visibility a different meaning for variables?
> At that point packages choosing so can simply use that. It's going to quite a bit of time for packages to migrate to this.
I get your point, default visibility has never been a good default, and it's probably hopeless to save it. Protected visibility is more or less defined as non-interposable export, so that and hidden visibility should satisfy nearly all uses. Default visibility could still be used for the rare case where a function should actually be interposable.
But I think that's what library writers have (in almost all cases) always wanted, but didn't use it because it didn't work and was recommended against. (GCC's man page says "protected and internal are pretty useless in real-world usage so the only other commonly used option is hidden." Drepper writes: "Only the first two [default and hidden] should ever be used.")
Still, protected visibility just doesn't interpose, it doesn't error out if there is a function with the same name. So while library writers can use it to opt out of interposition (which they probably didn't want in the first place), those who'd want to interpose just get a silent failure just as if we were making -fno-semantic-interposition the default. If library writers know about their users and whether someone might interpose their functions that could be helpful, but I don't know how often that's the case.
In any event, if library writers want to actively allow interposition, an explicit "weak" attribute would communicate that intent clearly.

(In reply to Aaron Puchert from comment #5) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #2) > > For C there's no ODR so things are more complicated. > What about C11 6.9.5? > > An external definition is an external declaration that is also a > definition of > a function (other than an inline definition) or an object. If an identifier > declared with external linkage is used in an expression (other than as > part of > the operand of a sizeof or _Alignof operator whose result is an integer > constant), somewhere in the entire program there shall be exactly one > external > definition for the identifier; otherwise, there shall be no more than one.
That doesn't constrain the semantics - it merely says that multiple definitions will be diagnosed by the linker and no definition as well. I think there's even a stronger guarantee somewhere that mismatched declarations (as in mismatched types) invoke undefined behavior.
Compare that to the C++ ODR which says (C++14, 3.2(6)):
"There can be more than one definition [...] - each definition of D shall consist of the same sequence of tokens; and [...]"
You possibly can read the C variant as being even stronger, but then even for C there are "multiple definitions", namely for C99 inline functions, and I don't see (OK, did not exhaustively search the standard) that the standard constrains the inline function definitions.

Normally I do like language lawyering very much, but I think in this case it's not appropriate. Symbol interposition is an ELF feature, and hence, for us, a system feature; a fairly powerful one with some disadvantages. We can't just disable that feature after 30 years. At least not if there are ways where we can mitigate the disadvantages without throwing out the baby completely.
Aaron: the power of interposition doesn't lie in being able to override known symbols, but rather to override _all_ (exported) symbols. The point being that the software authors don't have to explicitely mark symbols as overridable; if they were to be required to do that, that wouldn't then make it different from them explicitely designing hooks into their interfaces. There is for instance software that hooks many libc routines (and a changeable set of other routines) in order to, well, hook them (e.g. for tracing). Symbol interposition makes this trivial. Without it you need to resort to the contortions that equivalent Windows software needs to go through (basically patching either the import table, if it exists, or even the function code itself).
Basically: if library authors would be required to make their exports hookable, we would end up with nothing being hookable. That is because the need for hooking can't be predicted; if someone needs it, it's usually not the library author but someone outside who doesn't necessarily (want to) have means to change the library.
As I've written elsewhere (probably in the above generic-abi thread): I'll concede that such hooking usually takes place for C symbols, not for other language symbols. (Though of course there's nothing that would currently prevent that, and of course e.g. valgrind does hook the global c++ allocation routines). So, I'd be willing to try disabling interposition for C++ symbols (with exceptions).
But before even that, we need to be clear what exactly we want to change and what the improvements of that change will be. Perhaps on a bit more than just clang (speedup due to fewer symbol lookups) and some anecdote from the web about cpython.
(FWIW: I do know that libqt also goes to lengths to reduce symbolic lookups, and libreoffice (at the time still openoffice) had the same problem, which is why we now have .gnu.hash, and KDE had the problem which is why we have (had) kdeinit. I.e. I know that symbolic lookups are a problem for some software (all C++!) but I also know that it's absolutely no problem at all for other software, which is why I'm hammering so much on the protected visibility, being _exactly_ the right tool for avoiding symbolic lookups from within shared libs)
And yes, Aaron: the idea for "fixing" protected vis is to not generate copy relocs for variables (i.e. cross module accesses will be indirect, like now but in the other direction). For function addresses something similar can be done; it must be the one from the defining module, not from the PLT slot in the exe. H.J. works on some patches that try to phase that into the world step by step to not break existing binaries.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > Normally I do like language lawyering very much, but I think in this case > it's not appropriate. Symbol interposition is an ELF feature, and hence, > for us, a system feature; a fairly powerful one with some disadvantages. Sure, this isn't only about what's legal and what isn't. The one definition rule does not just constrain me as programmer, it also allows me to better reason about what's happening. Because if I see a function call, and a definition with a matching signature, I know that's the function being called. That's arguably a cornerstone of (interprocedurally) understanding code.
With interposition I might have to ask myself as library author if my library will still behave well if random functions have their functionality replaced, and I'm not sure how one could come to such a conclusion, especially if there are also changes within the library.
> if they were to be required to [explicitly mark symbols as overridable], > that wouldn't then make it different from them explicitly designing hooks > into their interfaces. Fully agreed, though just overriding a function is obviously more comfortable.
> There is for instance software that hooks many libc routines (and a changeable > set of other routines) in order to, well, hook them (e.g. for tracing). Certainly many parts of libc are well-suited for this, especially all that invoke system calls. (It's a lot like mocking in that regard.)
When it comes to tracing: eBPF allows out-of-process tracing on any function (not just those with default visibility), so I think we have a good replacement there. What eBPF cannot do is valgrind-like instrumentation, but there is a quite limited set of functions that are interesting for that. It would be strange if someone wanted to instrument functions like sin, cos or strlen.
> Basically: if library authors would be required to make their exports > hookable, we would end up with nothing being hookable. That is because the > need for hooking can't be predicted; if someone needs it, it's usually not > the library author but someone outside who doesn't necessarily (want to) > have means to change the library. That's where I disagree. You're absolutely right that hooking would be done by users of the library, but just like a library author can decide which functions they expose to the outside world for calling, they can surely also decide what to expose for hooking. We're relying on that anyway, a hidden visibility function cannot be interposed, let alone static (internal linkage) functions.
Now I think it would go off the rails if I went into how to decide that, but basically good candidates for hooking are things that invoke system calls or have side effects, like IO of any kind. Bad candidates are functions that are "CPU only", like an FFT or a prime factorization, or decoding a media stream. Alternatively one could see them as pure functions, or functions operating on "value types" as opposed to types like file handles that have an identity. Hooking pure functions is not so interesting because they're memoizable, so when and how often they're called is to some extent meaningless.
> But before even that, we need to be clear what exactly we want to change > and what the improvements of that change will be. Perhaps on a bit more than > just clang (speedup due to fewer symbol lookups) and some anecdote from the > web about cpython. Right, libLLVM and libclang are probably a special case with their enormous set of default visibility symbols. And generally C++ seems to be a bit of an issue, as you noted, though I can't quite put my finger on why that is. Perhaps the ability to mark entire classes as default visibility (which also includes private and protected methods) instead of individual functions is a contributing factor.
That being said, I think that fixing protected visibility seems like it would solve the problem as well, at least in the long term. Surely it will take projects time to switch when only the newest gcc/binutils properly support that.
While we're there, couldn't we make protected visibility even stricter and let the dynamic linker error out if there are two symbols of the same name? Like the static linker enforces every symbol having one definition. As I wrote earlier, this one-to-one correspondence is nice when trying to reason about code.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2022-27943: binutils: libiberty/rust-demangle.c in GNU GCC 11.2 allows stack exhaustion in demangle_const

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2022-27943
libiberty/rust-demangle.c in GNU GCC 11.2 allows stack consumption in demangle_const, as demonstrated by nm-new.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2022-27943 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-27943 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2022-27943/ https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=105039 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=28995
Upstream fix commit: https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/commit/f10bec5ffa487ad3033ed5f38cfd0fc7d696deab

(In reply to Thomas Leroy from comment #1) > Upstream fix commit: > https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/commit/ > f10bec5ffa487ad3033ed5f38cfd0fc7d696deab
That's for a different bug, upstream has not yet committed (but proposed) a fix.
Note the rust demangler is relatively new in gcc so gcc33, gcc43 and gcc48 are not affected. The rust demangler was introduced with gcc7.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #2) > (In reply to Thomas Leroy from comment #1) > > Upstream fix commit: > > https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/commit/ > > f10bec5ffa487ad3033ed5f38cfd0fc7d696deab > > That's for a different bug, upstream has not yet committed (but proposed) a > fix.
My bad Richard... Thanks for the clarification.
(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #3) > Note the rust demangler is relatively new in gcc so gcc33, gcc43 and gcc48 > are not affected. The rust demangler was introduced with gcc7.
Indeed. I am listing the vulnerable codestreams. I will list them down here and change the bug title in consequence

Btw, while GCC is one of the two canonical upstream sources of libiberty and thus rust-demangle.c I don't think any GCC package provided executable or library exposes rust demangling. c++filt is built from the binutils package.

Yeah, for SUSE as distro this will be a binutils bug report, only for upstream it's GCC, because libiberty is maintained there.
But just to say the obvious, once it's moved over to binutils this will be fixed only with the next binutils release, i.e. the next annular toolchain update in autumn. Note that SLE-11 (binutils 2.25) isn't affected, the rust demangler was introduced later. SLE-12 and SLE-15 are affected. I'll take this bug now, but it's going to be suspended until autumn.
Thanks for confirming Michael, and thanks for taking care of it. Tracking SUSE:SLE-12:Update, SUSE:SLE-15:Update and SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update as affected

I think SUSE:SLE-15:Update is wrong in that list. No currently supported product is based on that one, it's all from SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update (or later). (Please doublecheck, but this is what maintenance.suse.de tells me, and the assumption under which I did my last binutils updates).

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #8) > I think SUSE:SLE-15:Update is wrong in that list. No currently supported > product > is based on that one, it's all from SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update (or later). > (Please > doublecheck, but this is what maintenance.suse.de tells me, and the > assumption > under which I did my last binutils updates).
From https://smelt.suse.de/maintained/, you can see that for binutils, SUSE:SLE-15:Update is 'disabled' because it only contains LTSS channels. It actually means 'disabled by default'. In case of LTSS worthy bug (LTSS worthy is for us CVSS >= 7.0), this codestream still needs the patch so that LTSS customers get the fix. It's our job then to enable the LTSS channels.
So for that particular bug, you actually don't need to submit to SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update because the CVSS is not high enough, but for CVEs with a CVSS >= 7.0, this codestream would still require a submission, even though it is shown as disabled. I hope that I am clear :)

(In reply to Thomas Leroy from comment #9) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #8) > > I think SUSE:SLE-15:Update is wrong in that list. No currently supported > > product > > is based on that one, it's all from SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update (or later). > > (Please > > doublecheck, but this is what maintenance.suse.de tells me, and the > > assumption > > under which I did my last binutils updates). > > From https://smelt.suse.de/maintained/, you can see that for binutils, > SUSE:SLE-15:Update is 'disabled' because it only contains LTSS channels. It > actually means 'disabled by default'. In case of LTSS worthy bug (LTSS > worthy is for us CVSS >= 7.0), this codestream still needs the patch so that > LTSS customers get the fix. It's our job then to enable the LTSS channels.
I would go ballistic if any fuzzing non-sense CVE gets a CVSS >= 7.0.
> So for that particular bug, you actually don't need to submit to > SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update
SLE-15:Update, but yeah.
> because the CVSS is not high enough, but for CVEs > with a CVSS >= 7.0, this codestream would still require a submission, even > though it is shown as disabled. I hope that I am clear :)
You are, thanks.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2020-35448: binutils: heap-based buffer over-read in bfd_getl_signed_32() in libbfd.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2020-35448
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.35.1. A heap-based buffer over-read can occur in bfd_getl_signed_32 in libbfd.c because sh_entsize is not validated in _bfd_elf_slurp_secondary_reloc_section in elf.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35448 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-35448 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26574 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=8642dafaef21aa6747cec01df1977e9c52eb4679 https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20210129-0008/

This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1184794) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/256889 SLE-12 / binutils https://build.suse.de/request/show/256890 SLE-15-SP1 / binutils

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2021-3487: binutils: excessive debug section size can cause excessive memory consumption in bfd's dwarf2.c read_section()

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1947111
read_section() in dwarf2.c of BFD could cause excessive memory consumption when handling corrupt DWARF debug sections. This could lead to an impact to system availability, denial of service, and/or a crash in applications linked with the BFD library's DWARF functionality if they parse files from untrusted sources.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26946
Upstream patch commit: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=647cebce12a6b0a26960220caff96ff38978cf24
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1947111 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-3487 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2021-3487

bug.short_desc: Astonishing performance drop for strip of large binaries [ref:_00D1igLOd._5001ihamna:ref]

long_desc.thetext:
Our partner is observing that it takes around 40 times as long to strip one of their (large) binaries, which has ~100000 sections with strip from the binutils v2.35-7.11.1 maintenance update, compared to the 2.32-7.8.1 version shipping with SLE 15 SP2 FCS.
Detailed description: ===================== Working version and time taken: GNU strip (GNU Binutils; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 2.32.0.20190909-7.8 [...] -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1.5G Feb 26 08:47 /MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native real 0m6.353s user 0m5.364s sys 0m0.988s
Version with performance drop and time taken: GNU strip (GNU Binutils; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 2.35.0.20200915-7.11 (*) [...] -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1.5G Feb 26 08:47 /MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native real 4m12.192s user 4m10.777s sys 0m1.076s
The slowness appeared somewhere between 2.32 and 2.35.
Customer thinks the most interesting and relevant property of this binary is that it has almost 100000 sections which could possibly be the root cause. There seems to be a recent commits in strip and one of them even mentioned that things will go bad if the section count is large.
https://sourceware.org/git/?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=44466e45c51b1c68ed2f95f86bcdb1f18f08b380
FIXME: Currently this function can result in a serious performance penalty for files with secondary relocs and lots of sections. The proper way to fix this is for _bfd_elf_copy_special_section_fields() to chain secondary relocs together and then to have this function just walk that chain. */
Other interesting tidbit, the newer versions of objcopy are also equally slow for this giant binary. It is likely that the root cause is in some shared code between strip and objcopy.
Reproduction: ============= Yes, but unfortunately the specific binary cannot be shared. Hopefully the bit about 100000 sections could help with the reproduction. If not we could as a last resort ask the customer to try to create one.
Workaround possible: ==================== Yes, to use the 2.32 version of binutils
(*) I am currently waiting for a verification that the problem also exists on the current binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1. The bug will updated once this info is available.

Please excuse this somewhat premature bug with regards to awaiting confirmation that the problem persists on the latest version.
Customer name : Ericsson AB email domain : ericsson.com Architecture : x86_64 Case and refid : 00278678 ref:_00D1igLOd._5001iahslM:ref SG-ID : 60386
L3:60386 is now handled by Jean Delvare.

Unfortunately it does not look like the FIXME has been addressed upstream yet. So I don't think the maintenance update is going to help.
As I read it, the commit you mentioned is not causing the slowdown. It is only documenting it, and avoiding it when possible (which doesn't seem to be the case for your customer). I suspect that the actual slowdown comes from:
commit a8e14f4cc2badfcf959f5e2cc57a941dc43f72d4 Author: Nick Clifton Date: Thu Mar 5 15:47:15 2020 +0000
Add support for ELF files which contain multiple reloc sections which all target the same section.
which is also part of binutils 2.35. Michael will hopefully confirm this.
Michael, is reverting this specific change from SLES 15 SP2 an option for the time being? Or do we need to persuade upstream to implement the suggestion in the FIXME?

Please first verify that the problem still exists with binutils 2.35.1 as currently released as update for SLE-15.
Then, we need a reproducer. The mentioned commits only deal with secondary relocation sections, that is, ELF files where a section is affected by multiple relocation sections. Those are unusual and shouldn't occur trivially in the wild, which is why it's important to see the specifics of a reproducer.
As Jean already mentioned the actual slowdown (if it's really this problem!) will come from commit a8e14f4c, which implemented that support. Before it one should have gotten a warning message corresponding to this moved code:
- _bfd_error_handler - /* xgettext:c-format */ - (_("%pB: warning: multiple relocation sections for section %pA \ -found - ignoring all but the first"), - abfd, target_sect);
(a warning message should still be there!) commit 44466e4 merely improved the newly added code by not invoking it when not necessary (which should be the case for all normal ELF files that aren't specifically crafted to contain secondary relocation sections).
I've verified that the submitted binutils do contain both patches. Even the original maintenance update corresponding to version 2.35.0.20200915-7.11 should have contained both, but it can't hurt to verify that 2.35.1-7.18 still has the problem.

(In reply to Jean Delvare from comment #3) > Michael, is reverting this specific change from SLES 15 SP2 an option for > the time being?
That would reintroduce a bug with crafted binaries, and if this is really the same problem also affecting the customers binary it would also reintroduce a bug with _those_. (Seemingly a bug that was harmless before, which makes it even more important to see a reproducer to be sure that the mentioned commits are really the cause and not something completely different).
And before we invest much time in fixing the slowness problem of commit a8e14f4c we really want to be sure that we're barking up the right tree.

Customer has verified that the problem also exists on the latest binutils version :
224.76user 0.58system 3:46.15elapsed 99%CPU (0avgtext+0avgdata 356368maxresident)k 399800inputs+163120outputs (0major+109416minor)pagefaults 0swaps
I have asked them for a test binary to use and full output of the command dialog.

It appears that this test binary is difficult to get (even for my contact at the customer).
When running the strip command the output seems empty running it with the verbose option just results in the following line :
copy from 'MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native' [elf64-x86-64] to 'MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native.2.35.1.20201123' [elf64-x86-64]
Customer is asking if they should try some alternative options or could it be helpful for example to run with an strace or similar ?

Created attachment 848489 strace
My customer contact has given up on getting and/or producing a test binary. However he has provided an strace of an executing against the problematic binary. Hopefully this can be of use to the analysis at our end restarted.
Ping Michael

Well, I'm not sure what to do here, the strace doesn't show anything, except that there the program is doing stuff without syscalls in between, i.e. CPU work. Would the customer be willing to try a binutils version with the commit disabled (and hence susceptible to the bugs fixed with it), to see if that's really the one causing the speed problem?
Customer is willing to test a TEST package.

I built a TEST package for the customer:
https://ptf.suse.com/7a8fed5a4111fab9e4335fb24eb4e6ef/sle-module-basesystem-15-sp2/22260/x86_64/20210507-test
This package has the following 3 upstream commits reverted:
commit 790244d25897928fd5c950ee4e4ef84e3e9fd6ed (Note: This is the same as 44466e45c51b1c68ed2f95f86bcdb1f18f08b380 in a different branch.) Author: Nick Clifton <nickc@redhat.com> Date: Thu Sep 3 16:00:48 2020 +0100
Partially fix a quadratic slowdown when processing secondary relocations for inputs with lots of sections.
commit a859124df20f6544dbef96084e4e024bccebd853 Author: Alan Modra <amodra@gmail.com> Date: Wed Mar 18 07:31:47 2020 +1030
tidy elf_backend calls
commit a8e14f4cc2badfcf959f5e2cc57a941dc43f72d4 Author: Nick Clifton <nickc@redhat.com> Date: Thu Mar 5 15:47:15 2020 +0000
Add support for ELF files which contain multiple reloc sections which all target the same section.
Please have the customer give it a try and report.
Thanks, Jean. Passed on to customer.

My contact (not the originator) at the customer has tested the TEST package in a slightly different environment, but with a copy of the problematic binary at hand. Thus the times vary a little from comment 0. Still the results appear to support the analysis :
<snip> With the copy I have I did some tests and it seems to work for me. In short I think I can confirm that the change seems to work.
Fault recreated locally: bash-4.4# cp MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native binfile bash-4.4# time strip binfile -o binfile.strip
real 7m14.846s user 7m6.400s sys 0m2.043s bash-4.4# ls -lrt binfile* -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 2452517984 May 28 15:50 binfile -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 120421960 May 28 15:58 binfile.strip
bash-4.4# rpm -qa | egrep "binutils|libctf" libctf0-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64 libctf-nobfd0-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64 binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64
With the TEST rpms:
bash-4.4# cp MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native binfile bash-4.4# time strip binfile -o binfile.strip
real 0m9.473s user 0m6.025s sys 0m1.946s bash-4.4# ls -lrt binfile* -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 2452517984 May 28 15:59 binfile -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 120421960 May 28 15:59 binfile.strip
bash-4.4# rpm -qa | grep TEST libctf-nobfd0-2.35.1-7.18.1.22260.1.TEST.1183909.x86_64 binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.22260.1.TEST.1183909.x86_64 libctf0-2.35.1-7.18.1.22260.1.TEST.1183909.x86_64 </snip>
Michael, are you going to bring this up upstream and discuss it with Nick Clifton?

(In reply to Jean Delvare from comment #15) > Michael, are you going to bring this up upstream and discuss it with Nick > Clifton?
I don't see that helping without the binary, so no. But I'll try to fiddle with the patch myself to see if I can speed it up. I'll do that by doing assumptions on what the real problem will be, and in order to help with that reducing the possibilities would help.
So, if that large binary absolutely cannot be provided to me (which would be the best thing, and given we are under default NDAs should not actually be a problem) then at least the output of 'readelf -aW' on that binary would help. It should be sufficiently unspecific to not reveal any relevant secrets.

Customer has managed to provide a reproducer :
<snip> $ cat many_sections.sh
seq 100000 | xargs -I COUNTER echo 'int dataCOUNTER = COUNTER; __attribute__((section(".mytext_COUNTER"))) int myfuncCOUNTER() { return dataCOUNTER; }' > many_sections.cc
$ ./many_sections.sh $ g++ -g -c many_sections.cc -o many_sections.o $ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1 </snip>
I have verified it in a VM in my lab (2G of RAM, 8 vCPUs) :
$ rpm -q binutils binutils-2.32-7.8.1.x86_64
$ time many_sections.sh
real 0m55.144s user 0m43.896s sys 0m13.602s
$ sudo zypper up binutils $ rpm -q binutils binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64
$ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1
real 6m8.963s user 6m8.774s sys 0m0.168s

(In reply to Andreas Taschner from comment #17) Duh, Andreas ...
> $ time many_sections.sh ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Wrong output copied, sorry. That was of course supposed to be : $ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1
real 0m0.728s user 0m0.588s sys 0m0.124s
> $ sudo zypper up binutils > $ rpm -q binutils > binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64 > > $ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1 > > real 6m8.963s > user 6m8.774s > sys 0m0.168s
Hah, most excellent! To show that a local testcase really helps, I have a patch :-) https://sourceware.org/pipermail/binutils/2021-June/116869.html

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #19) > Hah, most excellent! To show that a local testcase really helps, I have > a patch :-) > https://sourceware.org/pipermail/binutils/2021-June/116869.html
Wonderful, thanks. Seeing that the patch is already accepted upstream, could we get the customer a PTF, Jean ?

Created attachment 850088 [PATCH] bfd/elf: Don't read non-existing secondary relocs
For the record, this is the patch I used to build the PTF.

PTF is available for download:
https://ptf.suse.com/7a8fed5a4111fab9e4335fb24eb4e6ef/sle-module-basesystem-15-sp2/22260/x86_64/20210609/
Please have the customer give it a try and report.
Customer has verified the PTF. Thank you all for getting this nailed.

Thanks. Ending L3 and passing over to maintenance.
Summary of the bug:
This is a performance regression introduced upstream in binutils version 2.35 (commit a8e14f4cc2ba - "Add support for ELF files which contain multiple reloc sections which all target the same section."). After this commit, the algorithm used by "strip" becomes quadratic, so a large binary with many sections would take a very long time to process.
The code can be optimized in such a way that only rare cases will trigger the quadratic behavior. In the common case, the algorithm becomes essentially linear again, solving the performance regression.

Customer is in need of a PTF for SLE 15 SP3. Could somebody kindly build that ?
Customer name : Ericsson AB email domain : ericsson.com Architecture : x86_64 Case and refid : 00308947 ref:_00D1igLOd._5001ihamna:ref SG-ID : 61355
L3:61355 is now handled by Tom Abraham.

PTF will appear at https://ptf.suse.com/7a8fed5a4111fab9e4335fb24eb4e6ef/sle-module-basesystem-15-sp3/22720/x86_64/20210805
Please provide feedback as soon as possible.
Thanks, Tom. The testcase from comment 17 did not compile on SLES 15 SP3, so I have asked the customer for a verification from them.
Customer has verified the SLE15-SP3 PTF. Thank you for quick turnaround.
was this included in the current binutils updates micha?
Yes it is included, but isn't referenced in the .changes file. It was the version update to 2.37 itself which fixed this. I'll make sure to mention it.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2021-20284: binutils: Heap-based buffer overflow in _bfd_elf_slurp_secondary_reloc_section in elf.c

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1937784
A flaw was found in GNU Binutils 2.35.1. There is a heap-based buffer overflow in _bfd_elf_slurp_secondary_reloc_section in elf.c because the number of symbols is not caculated correctly.
Upstream bug:
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26931
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1937784 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-20284

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2021-20197: binutils: race window allows users to own arbitrary files

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2021-20197
There is an open race window when writing output in the following utilities in GNU binutils version 2.35 and earlier: ar, objcopy, strip, ranlib. When these utilities are run as a privileged user (presumably as part of a script updating binaries across different users), an unprivileged user can trick these utilities into getting ownership of arbitrary files through a symlink.
References: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26945 https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1913743 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-20197

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2020-35507: binutils: NULL pointer dereference in bfd_pef_parse_function_stubs

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2020-35507
GNU Binutils before 2.34 has a NULL pointer dereference in bfd_pef_parse_function_stubs function in bfd/pef.c due to not checking return value of bfd_malloc. This bug allows attackers to cause a denial of service.
References: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25308 https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1911691 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35507
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=7a0fb7be96e0ce79e1ae429bc1ba913e5244d537

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2020-35496: binutils: multiple NULL pointer dereferences in bfd module due to not checking return value of bfd_malloc

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1911444
GNU Binutils before 2.34 has multiple NULL pointer deference bugs in bfd module due to not checking return value of bfd_malloc. This bug allows attackers to cause a denial of service.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25308
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1911444 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35496 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2020-35496

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2020-35493: binutils: heap-based buffer overflow in bfd_pef_parse_function_stubs function in bfd/pef.c via crafted PEF file

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1911437
Objdump of GNU Binutils before 2.34 has a heap-buffer-overflow in function bfd_pef_parse_function_stubs (file bfd/pef.c) which could allow attackers to cause a denial of service or unspecified impact.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25307
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1911437 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35493 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2020-35493
Upstream commit: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=f2a3559d54602cecfec6d90f792be4a70ad918ab

This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1180451) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/256889 SLE-12 / binutils https://build.suse.de/request/show/256890 SLE-15-SP1 / binutils

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2020-16598: binutils: Null Pointer Dereference in debug_get_real_type

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2020-16598
A Null Pointer Dereference vulnerability exists in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.34, in debug_get_real_type, as demonstrated in objdump, that can cause a denial of service via a crafted file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-16598 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-16598 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25840 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=ca3f923f82a079dcf441419f4a50a50f8b4b33c2

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2020-16592: binutils: use-after-free in bfd_hash_lookup

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2020-16592
A use after free issue exists in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd) in GNU Binutils 2.34 in bfd_hash_lookup, as demonstrated in nm-new, that can cause a denial of service via a crafted file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-16592 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-16592 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25823 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=7ecb51549ab1ec22aba5aaf34b70323cf0b8509a
