bug.short_desc: avr-gcc-10: skipping incompatible libgcc.a

long_desc.thetext:
Hello,
I am running
cross-avr-gcc10-10.1.1+git40-lp151.25.1.x86_64 cross-avr-binutils-2.34-lp151.386.1.x86_64
from obs://devel:gcc and I see the following issue which I believe should not be presented.
I am trying to build an example from Atmel ASF framework: https://www.microchip.com/mymicrochip/filehandler.aspx?ddocname=en1001769
# cd xdk-asf-3.48.0/mega/applications/mega-1284p_xplained_example/gcc # make V=1
I see the following error:
avr-gcc -mmcu=atmega1284p -Os -pipe -Wl,--relax -Wl,--gc-sections -Wl,-Map=mega_1284p_xplained.map,--cref -L../../../../mega/applications/mega-1284p_xplained_example mega/applications/mega-1284p_xplained_example/init.o mega/applications/mega-1284p_xplained_example/mega_1284p_xplained_example.o mega/applications/mega-1284p_xplained_example/usart.o mega/boards/mega_1284p_xplained/init.o mega/applications/mega-1284p_xplained_example/qt_asm_tiny_mega.o -lavr51g1-4qt-k-0rs -o mega_1284p_xplained.elf /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/ld: warning: -z relro ignored /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/ld: skipping incompatible /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/avr51/libgcc.a when searching for -lgcc /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/ld: skipping incompatible /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/libgcc.a when searching for -lgcc /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/ld: cannot find -lgcc collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status make: *** [../../../../common/utils/make/Makefile.avr.in:422: mega_1284p_xplained.elf] Error 1
I believe that /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/avr51/libgcc.a is skipped mistakenly. cross-avr-gcc8 package from devel:gcc is able to build and link this project successfully, cross-avr-gcc9 has the same issue.
Introducing "-Wl,--accept-unknown-input-arch" option to gcc fixes the build for gcc-10.
How could I further debug the issue?

Hum, I have next to no knowledge about AVR pecularities here so if you think that avr51/libgcc.a is "good" then it would be interesting to see why ld rejects it (I only see subtle differences in the objects, namely ELF Header 'Flags' are different but readelf does not in any way pretty-print those).
You can also try to add -v to the compiler command to see whether new GCC pass some different -m flags to the linker.
I suppose the issue reproduces even with a trivial 'int main() {}' program as soon as you use -mmcu=atmega1284p?

You are right, the issue is present when dummy C file is compiled as the following:
# avr-gcc -v -mmcu=atmega1284p test.c
Using built-in specs. Reading specs from /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/device-specs/specs-atmega1284p COLLECT_GCC=avr-gcc COLLECT_LTO_WRAPPER=/usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/lto-wrapper Target: avr Configured with: ../configure --prefix=/usr --infodir=/usr/share/info --mandir=/usr/share/man --libdir=/usr/lib64 --libexecdir=/usr/lib64 --enable-languages=c,c++ --enable-checking=release --disable-werror --with-gxx-include-dir=/usr/include/c++/10 --enable-ssp --disable-libssp --disable-libvtv --disable-cet --disable-libcc1 --disable-plugin --with-bugurl=https://bugs.opensuse.org/ --with-pkgversion='SUSE Linux' --with-slibdir=/lib64 --with-system-zlib --enable-libstdcxx-allocator=new --disable-libstdcxx-pch --enable-version-specific-runtime-libs --with-gcc-major-version-only --enable-linker-build-id --enable-linux-futex --enable-gnu-indirect-function --program-suffix=-10 --program-prefix=avr- --target=avr --disable-nls --with-sysroot=/usr/avr/sys-root --with-build-sysroot=/usr/avr/sys-root --with-build-time-tools=/usr/avr/bin --enable-lto --without-gxx-include-dir --with-native-system-header-dir=/include --build=x86_64-suse-linux --host=x86_64-suse-linux Thread model: single Supported LTO compression algorithms: zlib gcc version 10.1.1 20200507 [revision dd38686d9c810cecbaa80bb82ed91caaa58ad635] (SUSE Linux) COLLECT_GCC_OPTIONS='-v' '-mdouble=32' '-mlong-double=64' '-specs=device-specs/specs-atmega1284p' '-mmcu=avr51' /usr/lib64/gcc/avr/10/cc1 -quiet -v -imultilib avr51 -D__AVR_ATmega1284P__ -D__AVR_DEVICE_NAME__=atmega1284p test.c -mn-flash=2 -mno-skip-bug -quiet -dumpbase test.c -mdouble=32 -mlong-double=64 -mmcu=avr51 -auxbase test -version -o /tmp/ccLCyfEk.s GNU C17 (SUSE Linux) version 10.1.1 20200507 [revision dd38686d9c810cecbaa80bb82ed91caaa58ad635] (avr) compiled by GNU C version 7.5.0, GMP version 6.1.2, MPFR version 4.0.1, MPC version 1.1.0, isl version isl-0.18-GMP

Maybe the way the static library is compiled (or linked) is broken. We are now allowing debugedit to see them and maybe it somehow manages to break things ...
Unfortunately, I know little to nothing about ARM specifics for ELF. The long way would be to follow the error path in avr-ld.

Hi, from my mail to the opensuse-factory list:
I have a successfully building ltrace for OpenSUSE:Leap:15.2 (see https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:msalle:branches:openSUSE:Leap:15.2/ltrace)
all changes relate to the failing 'make check'. It has a new patch testsuite.patch: - it fixes the warnings from make check - it removes one entry which is using long double which isn't supported by ltrace while the test assumed it did (I actually have a quite extensive patch that enables long double, at least for my 64-bit Leap 15.1).
Plus some small changes to the spec file: - put make check inside a %check - it enforces using en_US.UTF-8 for running the tests, otherwise wchar.exp fails. Another UTF-8 locale should be fine too, but not setting it breaks the tests.

bug.short_desc: GCC9 wrong handling of builtin_constant_p()

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 835407 Reproducer
GCC9 does not handle builtin_constant_p() correctly in some cases. The offending statement is this:
buf->f_bavail = div_u64(total_free_data, factor);
However, factor is not a build-time constant. It is initialized to 1, but it may be later set to the result of an extern function call (i.e. GCC cannot make any assumptions about its return value).
IIUC GCC does not know with any certainty whether the value is constant, or not, so it generates code for both cases.
The code is originally taken from the Linux kernel sources, fails because of unresolved references to __aeabi_uldivmod. I have trimmed it down and made it self-contained. It is not (yet) a minimal reproducer, but getting close. Build it with a 32-bit ARM compiler (native or cross-compiler) like this:
$ gcc-9 -nostdinc -std=gnu89 -marm -march=armv7-a -O2 -c gcc9-arm-div.c -o gcc9-arm-div.o
I used native gcc-9 from openSUSE:Leap:15.2:ARM to verify the bug:
$ gcc-9 -v Using built-in specs. COLLECT_GCC=gcc-9 COLLECT_LTO_WRAPPER=/usr/lib/gcc/armv7hl-suse-linux-gnueabi/9/lto-wrapper Target: armv7hl-suse-linux-gnueabi Configured with: ../configure --prefix=/usr --infodir=/usr/share/info --mandir=/usr/share/man --libdir=/usr/lib --libexecdir=/usr/lib --enable-languages=c,c++,fortran,go --disable-werror --with-gxx-include-dir=/usr/include/c++/9 --enable-ssp --disable-libssp --disable-libvtv --disable-cet --disable-libcc1 --disable-plugin --with-bugurl=https://bugs.opensuse.org/ --with-pkgversion='SUSE Linux' --with-slibdir=/lib --with-system-zlib --enable-libstdcxx-allocator=new --disable-libstdcxx-pch --enable-version-specific-runtime-libs --with-gcc-major-version-only --enable-linker-build-id --enable-linux-futex --enable-gnu-indirect-function --program-suffix=-9 --without-system-libunwind --with-arch=armv7-a --with-tune=cortex-a15 --with-float=hard --with-abi=aapcs-linux --with-fpu=vfpv3-d16 --disable-sjlj-exceptions --build=armv7hl-suse-linux-gnueabi --host=armv7hl-suse-linux-gnueabi Thread model: posix gcc version 9.2.1 20190820 [gcc-9-branch revision 274748] (SUSE Linux)
It can also be reproduced with a cross-compiler.
*** Bug 1169132 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to Petr Tesařík from comment #1) > *** Bug 1169132 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
If you want to see the original sources, they are attached to that bug.

Ouch. There's nothing "wrong" here - GCC expects to have access to libgcc. That your "optimization" using __builtin_constant_p falls apart is a missed optimization.
I'm not 100% sure where it goes "wrong", but I see things like a long chain of
<bb 44> : _49 = divisor_3(D) & 1073741824; if (_49 == 0) goto <bb 45>; [50.00%] else goto <bb 74>; [50.00%]
<bb 45> : _50 = divisor_3(D) & 536870912; if (_50 == 0) goto <bb 46>; [50.00%] else goto <bb 74>; [50.00%] ...
<bb 72> : _77 = divisor_3(D) & 4; if (_77 != 0) goto <bb 74>; [50.00%] else goto <bb 73>; [50.00%]
<bb 73> :
<bb 74> : # iftmp.68_80 = PHI <1(42), 2147483648(43), 1073741824(44), 536870912(45), 268435456(46), 134217728(47), 67108864(48), 33554432(49), 16777216(50), 8388608(51), 4194304(52), 2097152(53), 1048576(54), 524288(55), 262144(56), 131072(57), 65536(58), 32768(59), 16384(60), 8192(61), 4096(62), 2048(63), 1024(64), 512(65), 256(66), 128(67), 64(68), 32(69), 16(70), 8(71), 4(72), 2(73)> _78 = (long long unsigned int) divisor_3(D); _79 = 18446744073709551615 / _78; ...
with the expectation of the compiler to force constant evaluation of the code along all conditional edges.
A __builtin_constant_p guarding conditional does _not_ force constant evaluation on all expressions dependent on the constant argument.
Of course the issue here is likely the appearant jump threading opportunity here:
if (__builtin_constant_p(__base) && is_power_of_2(__base)) { __rem = (dividend) & (__base - 1); (dividend) >>= ilog2(__base); } else if (__builtin_constant_p(__base) && __base != 0) {
it's tempting to factor the common conditional given that is_power_of_2 starts is
bool is_power_of_2(unsigned long n) { return (n != 0 && ((n & (n - 1)) == 0));
not sure what that constant && is_power_of_2 really should do here, it looks like premature optimization. Removing that case "fixes" the issue. I expect refactoring the code to common the
if (__builtin_constant_p(__base) && __base != 0)
as outermost conditional and _inside_ of it special-casing if (is_power_of_2 ()) might help, too.
So, not really a bug IMHO, just a bogus expectation.

I've had a look at the generated assembly code. The code between the loop and the call to spin_lock() has two variants:
A. when the loop has been run at least once. -> r5 is set to 0 B. when the loop condition was initially false. -> r5 is set to 1
I believe r5 corresponds to __builtin_constant_p(factor), and that's what gets checked after spin_unlock(). But the whole point of checking __builtin_constant_p() was to do some expensive calculations only if they can be performed at build-time. I wonder if there's a better way to achieve that goal...

Hm, I decided to torture GCC a bit, so I added this line to the function:
static const int is_constant = builtin_constant_p(factor);
And now I'm getting:
gcc9-arm-div.c: In function 'btrfs_statfs': gcc9-arm-div.c:494:33: error: initializer element is not constant 494 | static const int is_constant = builtin_constant_p(factor); | ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
This is somewhat contrary to the official documentation of builtin_constant_p(), which says:
> You may also use '__builtin_constant_p' in initializers for static > data. For instance, you can write > > static const int table[] = { > __builtin_constant_p (EXPRESSION) ? (EXPRESSION) : -1, > /* ... */ > }; > > This is an acceptable initializer even if EXPRESSION is not a > constant expression, including the case where > '__builtin_constant_p' returns 1 because EXPRESSION can be folded > to a constant but EXPRESSION contains operands that are not > otherwise permitted in a static initializer (for example, '0 && foo > ()'). GCC must be more conservative about evaluating the built-in > in this case, because it has no opportunity to perform > optimization.
So, I beg to treat the current GCC9 behaviour as a bug.

If you are fine with __builtin_constant_p() being unknown at build time then just #define it to false ... seriously esp. kernel folks wanted to have as many __builtin_constant_p () resolved to true as possible. This is why we are resolving it to false so late. And this is why these issues pop up because GCC shoots itself^Wthe developer in the foot with code transforms in between the source AST and the point we are resolving __builtin_constant_p to false.
The circumstances where things "break" (usually they break in a more invisble way than here) are rare but probably unavoidable.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #10) >[...] > (I will note that the problem for the kernel here is non trivial: even if they > were to provide an implementation of the division function of libgcc.a, it > would then indeed be called at runtime, and the whole point was to not have > to do the expensive division)
I tend to agree. It has never been clear to me why the kernel re-invents the wheel. GCC is certainly clever enough to replace a divide-by-constant with a multiply-by-reciprocal. There might have been some ancient GCC versions which could not do that, but I doubt they are used to build the kernel by anyone.

It is not exactly nice that you have to link modules to the helper in the kernel. It may be also problematic if simple division emits a function call someplace where you are inside an exception handler with only limited memory mappings installed and user registers that are in need of saving.
Still it's done for 32bit division anyway so all this does already happen.
It sure requires that somebody implements these 64bit helpers but cut and pasting from libgcc should be license-compatible.

(In reply to Michal Suchanek from comment #12) > Still it's done for 32bit division anyway so all this does already happen.
As a matter of fact, it's even done for 64-bit division. If none of the shortcuts can be taken, do_div() does this:
__rem = __div64_32(&(n), __base);
Now, __div64_32() on arm is implemented in inline assembly as:
"bl __do_div64"
The rest of the function merely makes sure that input/output registers are assigned correctly.
Note we may not have special optimized 64bit / 32bit division handling.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #14) > Note we may not have special optimized 64bit / 32bit division handling.
Bummer.
Shall I file a feature request for a future GCC version?

(In reply to Petr Tesařík from comment #15) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #14) > > Note we may not have special optimized 64bit / 32bit division handling. > > Bummer. > > Shall I file a feature request for a future GCC version?
I can handle that for upstream (a SUSE bugzilla isn't helpful). But it would need details on what can be optimized [on specific targets], for example with testcases with specific (non-)constants.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18484: binutils: Stack Exhaustion in the C++ demangling functions provided by libiberty, caused by recursive stack frames

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18484 An issue was discovered in cp-demangle.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. Stack Exhaustion occurs in the C++ demangling functions provided by libiberty, and there is a stack consumption problem caused by recursive stack frames: cplus_demangle_type, d_bare_function_type, d_function_type.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18484 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-18484/

bug.short_desc: ld encountering segmentation fault on x86_64

long_desc.thetext:
ld from the newly released maintenance update, i.e. binutils-2.32-9.33.1, is encountering segmentation fault on x86_64 at least when building pacemaker.
Found by L3 engineer when trying to build TEST/PTF package for a customer: https://bugzilla.suse.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1151007#c8
It's also occurring in my test branch: https://build.suse.de/package/live_build_log/home:yan_gao:branches:SUSE:SLE-12-SP4:Update:Test:Test/pacemaker/standard/x86_64
Michael, could you please take a look at this? Thanks.
Yes, mine. I have a patch.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-19932: binutils: integer overflow and infinite loop caused by the IS_CONTAINED_BY_LMA

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-19932
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils through 2.31. There is an integer overflow and infinite loop caused by the IS_CONTAINED_BY_LMA macro in elf.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-19932 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-19932.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-19932

bug.short_desc: gcc doesn't work when bash isn't the login shell

long_desc.thetext:
gcc fails with the below error when fish is the login shell: simon@tek-top ~/src/tmp ➤ gcc -o locale locale.c gcc: error trying to exec 'cc1': execvp: No such file or directory
if I run the same command inside bash --login it compiles fine. So at a guess we are setting some environment variables in a bash only location.
This issue is also in Leap 15, earlier versions of Leap and Tumbleweed did not have this issue.

You need to provide more information here. We don't have any GCC specific environment. Can you provide strace output of the failing command? Can you provide the environment contents of your fish login shell (and that in case of bash, just for completeness?).
Also, output of 'gcc -v -o locale locale.c'.

At a hunch that I still need to confirm, I suspect this is because fish doesn't load /etc/profile and as such environment variables like HOST CPU OSTYPE MACHTYPE aren't loaded. But I need to find some time to investigate this better.

GCC doesn't use those.
The driver as of today looks at
getenv("TERM") = "xterm" getenv("GCC_EXEC_PREFIX") = nil getenv("PATH") = "/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin" getenv("PATH") = "/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin" getenv("COMPILER_PATH") = nil getenv("LIBRARY_PATH") = nil getenv("LPATH") = nil getenv("GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG") = nil getenv("GCC_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("MAKEFLAGS") = nil
the error from the driver means it cannot find cc1.
Maybe you have _bogus_ (GCC_EXEC_PREFIX?) environment with fish?

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2014-5044: gcc: integer overflow flaws in libgfortran

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2014-5044
Multiple integer overflow issues were found in libgfortran, the run-time support library for the Fortran compiler. These could possibly be used to crash a Fortran application or cause it to execute arbitrary code.
Upstream fix:
https://gcc.gnu.org/viewcvs/gcc?limit_changes=0&view=revision&revision=211721
These will be included in a later release of GCC.
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1122812

Dear Maintainer,
to make our process faster and better we need you to provide the information for each maintained product where it is currently missing:
Affected | gcc | |====== core9-sp3-teradata | ? | sles10-sp3-teradata | ? | sles11-sp1-teradata | ? | sles11-sp3 | ? |
Please also consider OpenSUSE (12.3, 13.1, Factory) and SLE-12
if you are unsure if the maintained package is vulnerable or not, we will assist you.
Happy hacking! Your Security Team
bugbot adjusting priority

(In reply to comment #1) > Dear Maintainer, > > to make our process faster and better we need you to provide the information > for each maintained product where it is > currently missing: > > Affected | gcc | > |====== > core9-sp3-teradata | ? | > sles10-sp3-teradata | ? | > sles11-sp1-teradata | ? | > sles11-sp3 | ? | > > Please also consider OpenSUSE (12.3, 13.1, Factory) and SLE-12 > > if you are unsure if the maintained package is vulnerable or not, we will > assist you.
All but core9-sp3-teradata (that's based on SLE9?) are affected. Note that fortran (and thus libgfortran) is not supported (it's on the SDK only).
The SLE12 codebase is also affected.
Thus, no updates planned unless I get an explicit request through proper channels.
> > Happy hacking! > Your Security Team

Affected packages:
SLE-10-SP3-TERADATA: gcc SLE-11-SP3: gcc
Correction, SLE-11-SP3 affected package is gcc47 as that is where the libgfortran runtime comes from, not gcc or gcc43. On SLE-12-GA the affected package is gcc48.
Upstream has backports up to GCC 4.8, I am preparing an updated compiler for SLE-12-GA.
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (888791) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/42117 SLE-12 / gcc48
This is an autogenerated message for OBS integration: This bug (888791) was mentioned in https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/248457 Factory / gcc48
This is an autogenerated message for OBS integration: This bug (888791) was mentioned in https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/264390 Factory / gcc49
Security team: please advise. Should we or should we not also do an update for sle10-sp3-teradata? It's an unbelievably old compiler and I severely doubt that teradata is using fortran there.
hi for know you dont have to backport it to teradata.
Okay, AFAICS this then leaves only gcc47 for SLE11-SP3. If you need one, please request an update.
we will include this in the next gcc update

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2015-8538: libdwarf: a out of bound read bug is found in libdwarf

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2015-8538
There is a out of bound read in latest release version dwarf-20151114, and we have tested the other version dwarf-20140805, so we guess the versions which are between these two version will be affected too. when an odd elf file passed to dwarfdump, it would cause segment fault by invalid memory access. please see the attachment for the elf file.
========================================= Details: ==========================================
if an elf file is passed to dwarfdump, a SIGSEGV will occur in libdwarf/dwarf_leb.c. please see attachment for the elf file.
when debugging it with gdb, the error information as follows:
-------------------------------- Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault. _dwarf_decode_u_leb128 (leb128=leb128@entry=0x80006a5be7a4 <error: Cannot access memory at address 0x80006a5be7a4>, leb128_length=leb128_length@entry=0x7fffffffda68) at dwarf_leb.c:57 57 if ((*leb128 & 0x80) == 0) {
(gdb) bt #0 _dwarf_decode_u_leb128 (leb128=leb128@entry=0x80006a5be7a4 <error: Cannot access memory at address 0x80006a5be7a4>, leb128_length=leb128_length@entry=0x7fffffffda68) at dwarf_leb.c:57 #1 0x00000000004319fb in dwarf_attrlist (die=die@entry=0x6bb850, attrbuf=attrbuf@entry=0x7fffffffdb18, attrcnt=attrcnt@entry=0x7fffffffdb10, error=0x67c298 <err>) at dwarf_query.c:246 #2 0x0000000000410909 in print_one_die (dbg=dbg@entry=0x67ef00, die=die@entry=0x6bb850, print_information=1, die_indent_level=1, srcfiles=srcfiles@entry=0x0, cnt=cnt@entry=0, ignore_die_stack=ignore_die_stack@entry=0) at print_die.c:1211 #3 0x00000000004111d8 in print_die_and_children_internal (dbg=dbg@entry=0x67ef00, in_die_in=0x6a4a30, is_info=is_info@entry=1, srcfiles=srcfiles@entry=0x0, cnt=cnt@entry=0) at print_die.c:896 #4 0x00000000004115e5 in print_die_and_children_internal (dbg=dbg@entry=0x67ef00, in_die_in=0x6811a0, is_info=is_info@entry=1, srcfiles=0x0, cnt=0) at print_die.c:990 #5 0x0000000000411d1f in print_die_and_children (cnt=<optimized out>, srcfiles=<optimized out>, is_info=1, in_die_in=<optimized out>, dbg=0x67ef00) at print_die.c:778 #6 print_one_die_section (dbg=0x67ef00, is_info=is_info@entry=1) at print_die.c:725 #7 0x00000000004126a3 in print_infos (dbg=<optimized out>, is_info=is_info@entry=1) at print_die.c:319 #8 0x000000000040217a in process_one_file (config_file_data=0x6660c0 <config_file_data>, archive=0, tied_file_name=0x0, file_name=0x67d110 "./simplereader.elf", elftied=0x0, elf=<optimized out>) at dwarfdump.c:1280 #9 main (argc=<optimized out>, argv=<optimized out>) at dwarfdump.c:630
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1289385 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2015-8538 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2015/q4/464

Created attachment 658937 simplereader.zip
QA REPRODUCER:
ELF inside zip
dwarfdump simplereader.elf
will segfault
(dwarfdump can be gotten from SUSE:SLE-11:GA libdwarf subpackage,
osci getbinaries SUSE:SLE-11:GA libdwarf standard x86_64 )

There are not much tools using libdwarf in SLE11.
CodeAnalyst is the main one, although I never used it.
bugbot adjusting priority

bug.short_desc: ltrace attaching to multi-threaded applications killed by SIGTRAP
bug.product: SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11 SP4 (SLES 11 SP4)

long_desc.thetext:
Tested on SLES 11 SP4 Beta1 https://bugzilla.suse.com/tr_show_case.cgi?case_id=1441097 used C program from https://bugzilla.suse.com/show_bug.cgi?id=873460
dhcp235:~ # rpm -qa|grep ltrace ltrace-0.7.2-1.3 https://build.suse.de/request/show/49828
dhcp235:~ # ltrace -C -S -tt -f -n 2 -p `ps -C mpf-thread --no-headers | awk '{print$1}'` enable_breakpoint pid=6747, addr=0x8048550, symbol=printf: No such process enable_breakpoint pid=6747, addr=0x8048540, symbol=pthread_mutex_unlock: No such process PTRACE_SETOPTIONS: No such process [pid 6747] 13:26:38.171961 +++ killed by SIGTRAP +++
dhcp235:~ # ./mpf-thread Thread #1 started Thread #2 started Thread #3 started Thread #4 started Thread #5 started Thread #6 started Thread #7 started Thread #8 started Thread #9 started Thread #10 started Thread #11 started Thread #12 started Thread #13 started Thread #14 started Thread #15 started Thread #16 started
Press Enter to end Trace/breakpoint trap dhcp235:~ #
This bug is blocking testing of feature [317735] Test Feature: Make ltrace multi-threaded capable (version upgrade)

Yes, this particular bug is not yet fixed upstream. The version update we did was for general support of multi threaded programs, and that works now.
Longer version: what's supported now is to trace programs that create new threads while running. But _attaching_ to already existing processes that already have multiple threads does not work. As said, this is also the upstream behaviour, and it is also how RHEL7 ltrace behaves.
I haven't checked RHEL6 but presumably that'd behave the same, so the testcase from bug #873460 is invalid (or at least the claim that it works on redhat).
A testcase that does work is to use the same program, but not start it before ltrace and attach to it, but rather let ltrace start it itself:
% ltrace -C -S -tt -f -n 2 ./mpf-thread
(this will spew out much output as the threads are doing work, but essentially it'll wait on an enter press after which the process will stop normally)

bug.short_desc: gdb lacks hint about how to reload symbols

long_desc.thetext:
# gdb --readnow -p `pidof libvirtd` -ex continue -ex bt GNU gdb (GDB; SUSE Linux Enterprise 12) 7.7 ... Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault. [Switching to Thread 0x7f11fc822700 (LWP 2179)] 0x00007f1211f98be0 in virClassIsDerivedFrom () from /usr/lib64/libvirt.so.0 #0 0x00007f1211f98be0 in virClassIsDerivedFrom () from /usr/lib64/libvirt.so.0 #1 0x00007f1211f98e84 in virObjectLock () from /usr/lib64/libvirt.so.0 ... Missing separate debuginfos, use: zypper install libvirt-daemon-debuginfo-1.2.17-3.1.x86_64 (gdb)
The last line should also give a hint about how to actually use the new debuginfo once it got installed in another window. Google was not helpful, but reboot and try again worked...
Huh? Restart of gdb should be enough, isn't that obvious enough?

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > Huh? Restart of gdb should be enough, isn't that obvious enough?
That would lose the info from the just crashed process, right?
So, can gdb reload the entire thing? It seems to be able to handle a new pkg-debugsource somewhat. One has to do something like 'up ; down' to see the code for the current frame.

(In reply to Olaf Hering from comment #2) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #1) > > Huh? Restart of gdb should be enough, isn't that obvious enough? > > That would lose the info from the just crashed process, right?
Sure, though you could preserve at least a core file.
> So, can gdb reload the entire thing? It seems to be able to handle a new > pkg-debugsource somewhat. One has to do something like 'up ; down' to see > the code for the current frame.
I am not aware of any mechanism to tell gdb to reload the whole thing without re-starting the debugging session (detach / re-attach for example, but with the same issue of losing the crash).
That doesn't mean it does not exist - I am not very familiar with the very many commands of gdb.
Oh, and I won't implement this feature (I am not a gdb developer), so filing gdb enhancement requests in SUSE bugzilla is quite useless. May I suggest to go to sourceware.org/bugzilla instead?

I'm fine with an additional line which says something like: restart of gdb required once the required packages are installed. use "$cmd" to create a coredump: use "$cmd" to inspect that coredump file.
I assume that refering to zypper install is out feature.
s/out/our/
Well, ok... queued as low-priority item.

Potentially we could use something like symbol-file or add-symbol-file, but atm that doesn't work for me ( PR24810 - "add-symbol-file for shared lib has no effect" https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24810 ).

bug.short_desc: binutils: strip lefts temporary files

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 809150 crypto.o
Hi,
I am running Leap 15.1 with binutils-2.31-lp151.2.29.x86_64
When running strip as the following (please, find crypto.o attached)
strip -p --strip-debug --discard-locals -R .comment -R .note crypto.o
I see lots of error messages (that is ok), and empty file created in the working directory st1b7FZK. The filename is always random prefixed by "st". Leaving empty files is NOT okay, even if I am feeding strip with a garbage.
You may wonder: why do you do that? Answer is simple: this issue has implications on the build process in OBS for erlang package. strip is run by brp-15-strip-debug on this file, leaving hardly avoidable empty files in the resulting RPM package. This files also have 0600 permissions, that triggers some other issues.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10534: binutils: out-of-bounds memory write in _bfd_XX_bfd_copy_private_bfd_data_common function in peXXigen.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-10534
The _bfd_XX_bfd_copy_private_bfd_data_common function in peXXigen.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, processes a negative Data Directory size with an unbounded loop that increases the value of (external_IMAGE_DEBUG_DIRECTORY) *edd so that the address exceeds its own memory region, resulting in an out-of-bounds memory write, as demonstrated by objcopy copying private info with _bfd_pex64_bfd_copy_private_bfd_data_common in pex64igen.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10534 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23110

bug.short_desc: linking i386 fails with assertion in bfd/elf.c:3564

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 764064 rombios_32bit.tar.gz
Since recently home:olh:xen-unstable/xen fails to build in Tumbleweed:
[ 329s] make[10]: Entering directory '/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/xen-4.11.20180316T205828.0012ae8afb/non-dbg/tools/firmware/rombios/32bit' [ 330s] ld -melf_i386 -s -r 32bitbios.o tcgbios/tcgbiosext.o util.o pmm.o -o 32bitbios_all.o [ 330s] ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; openSUSE Tumbleweed) 2.30.0.20180226-2 assertion fail ../../bfd/elf.c:3564
Removing -g3 from CFLAGS fixes it. See attached testcase.
Perhaps 'zypper in xen-devel', it happens to work for me.
Created attachment 764080 rombios_32bit.tar.gz

Ok, so
ld -melf_i386 -s -r 32bitbios.bad.o -o 32bitbios_all.bad.o
is enough to reproduce this. separately stripping works for me. I guess nobody uses -s.
Using -g3 -gstrict-dwarf also makes it work.
Without -gstrict-dwarf we have
[ 1] .group GROUP 00000000 000034 00000c 04 23 15 4 [ 2] .group GROUP 00000000 000040 00000c 04 23 16 4 [13] .debug_macro PROGBITS 00000000 0000ff 0008e1 00 0 0 1 [14] .rel.debug_macro REL 00000000 00386c 000aa0 08 I 23 13 4 [15] .debug_macro PROGBITS 00000000 0009e0 000016 00 G 0 0 1 [16] .rel.debug_macro REL 00000000 00430c 000018 08 IG 23 15 4 [17] .debug_macro PROGBITS 00000000 0009f6 000052 00 G 0 0 1 [18] .rel.debug_macro REL 00000000 004324 000068 08 IG 23 17 4
COMDAT group section [ 1] `.group' [wm4.stdcpredef.h.19.3bd61da18dac034cbf4a4b99f8f2e646] contains 2 sections: [Index] Name [ 15] .debug_macro [ 16] .rel.debug_macro
COMDAT group section [ 2] `.group' [wm4.rombios_compat.h.2.d518a25213ddee794b75640ef514494a] contains 2 sections: [Index] Name [ 17] .debug_macro [ 18] .rel.debug_macro
and with there's no extra group nor any relocation for .debug_macro.
Testcase:
> echo '#define FOO BAR' > t.c > gcc-7 t.c -g3 -c > ld -r -s t.o -o tx.o ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; devel:gcc / openSUSE_Leap_42.2) 2.30.0.20180226-0 assertion fail ../../bfd/elf.c:3564 ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; devel:gcc / openSUSE_Leap_42.2) 2.30.0.20180226-0 assertion fail ../../bfd/elf.c:3564
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22981
I suggest to stop using ld -s.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-7208: gdb,binutils: In the coff_pointerize_aux function in coffgen.c in the Binary File Descriptor(BFD) library an index is not validated, which allows remote attackers to cause DoS

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-7208
In the coff_pointerize_aux function in coffgen.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, an index is not validated, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (segmentation fault) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted file, as demonstrated by objcopy of a COFF object.
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1546622 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-7208 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-7208/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22741

Upstream bug: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22741 Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=eb77f6a4621795367a39cdd30957903af9dbb815
All supported codestreams are affected for both gdb as well as binutils.

bug.short_desc: dynamic linker relocates absolute symbols in executables linked with -pie

long_desc.thetext: This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1112570) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/176388 SLE-15-SP1 / glibc
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1112570) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/180553 SLE-15 / glibc
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1112570) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/186224 SLE-15 / glibc

Hello, I'm testing the update (qam-sle) on misanthrope, a SLES 15 refhost. I get the following results, and I'm not sure whether or not the patch is working as expected (I'd say no):
misanthrope:~ # ./reproducer.good start=0x601048 end=0x601088 size=0x40
misanthrope:~ # ./reproducer.bad start=0x55b6696c9048 end=0x55b6696c9088 size=0x55b6694c8040
Size should be 0x40 in both cases, so the patch doesn't seem to work as expected for the -pie case.
x86_64: does not work aarch64: it works ppc64le: does not work
The linker is emitting a RELATIVE relocation against the symbol. So this needs additional support from the linker.
@Andreas I guess I can reject S:M:9959:185968 right?
Why?
Because the RR reports that this issue is fixed while it's not. Or am I missing something??
It needs more support from the linker, but otherwise it is fixed.

bug.short_desc: The gstack command sometimes hangs

long_desc.thetext:
This has been dupicated on sles 12 sp2, sp3, and sp4.
Instructions to reproduce the issue are attached. The customer has included his proposed fix.

Customer: IBM INTERNAL SR Number: 101214776981 Bug Number: 1123234 Issue Type: [0] Normal Severity: [-100] Normal Entitlement Type: [-100] Priority Workaround: [-20] No Environment: [-20] Production Frequency: [-10] Random # of Users Affected: [-50] 251-1000 Potential Users: [-15] 251-1000 DSLA Required: true NTS Defect Priority: 685
L3:53416 is now handled by Lidong Zhong.
Robert, could you attach the steps to reproduce this problem? Thanks.

For some reason, bugzilla is not allowing me to upload this file. I will paste it here: =========
gstack command sometimes hangs.
The customer reported the problem with sles12sp2 and I recreated the same issue on sles12sp3 and sp4
The problem can be recreated on my internal sles12sp3 system and the steps to recreate is as below.
(1) run many multi-thread processes (150 processes with 3 thread in each thread group)
(2) generate a list of those multi-thread processes (ps aux |grep xxxxx> nonnativeList )
(3) run gstack command by using following shell script
# for i in $(cat nonnativeList | awk '{print $2;}')
> do
> echo =============== $i ==========================
> gstack ${i}
> sleep 10
> done
(3) gstack hangs sometime late
The gstack command resumes processing if I send a SIGCONT to one of the thread which was stopped in "ptrace_stop" function. (eg. kill -SIGCONT xxxx)
sles12s3k:~ # ps -eflL |grep 40934
0 t root 40934 1 40934 0 3 80 0 - 37409 ptrace 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 40934 1 40985 0 3 80 0 - 37409 hrtime 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 t root 40934 1 40986 0 3 80 0 - 37409 ptrace 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
0 S root 41600 41432 41600 0 1 80 0 - 934 wait 14:35 pts/0 00:00:00 /bin/sh /usr/bin/gstack 40934
0 S root 41604 41600 41604 0 1 80 0 - 12067 sigsus 14:35 pts/0 00:00:00 gdb --quiet -nx /proc/40934/exe 40934
0 S root 41610 39443 41610 0 1 80 0 - 699 pipe_w 14:36 pts/2 00:00:00 grep --color=auto 40934
sles12s3k:~ # kill -SIGCONT 40986
sles12s3k:~ # ps -eflL |grep 40934
0 S root 40934 1 40934 0 3 80 0 - 37409 futex_ 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 40934 1 40985 0 3 80 0 - 37409 system 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 40934 1 40986 0 3 80 0 - 37409 hrtime 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
When the problem occurs the gstack command does not complete.
The gstack command executes a gdb command and waiting for its completion.
The gdb command is suspended in sigsuspend() like below.
(TASK status from my test result)
kernel: gdb S 0000000000674eea 0 29274 29270 0x00000000
kernel: 0000000000000001 0000000000ad2e00 00000000009930d8 0000000000000000
kernel: 0000000000000000 000000001620e898 000000001620e108 0000000037800e00
kernel: 000000001620e208 0000000000ad2e00 00000000009930d8 000000000099af00
kernel: 0000000000000000 000000001620e898 000000001620e108 0000000037800e00
kernel: 0000000000688a40 00000000006749a2 000000001666bde8 000000001666be50
kernel: Call Trace:
kernel: ([<00000000006749a2>] __schedule+0x2fa/0x7f8)
kernel: [<0000000000674eea>] schedule+0x4a/0xb0
kernel: [<00000000001518ea>] sigsuspend+0x5a/0xa0
kernel: [<000000000015366c>] SyS_rt_sigsuspend+0x4c/0x70
kernel: [<0000000000679698>] system_call+0xfc/0x290
kernel: [<000003ffad439b68>] 0x3ffad439b68
The task status
Hi Michael, could you please take a look at this problem? Thanks.
Where is the proposed fix from the customer? Is there a testcase that can be used to create that many processes with threads?
Tom, can you take care of this (& upstreaming in case it is not)?
Hi Robert, which version is the customer testing? The latest MU for SLE12SP3 is 8.2-2.9.4 which has already included the patch in comment#7.

(In reply to Robert Snow from comment #0) > This has been dupicated on sles 12 sp2, sp3, and sp4. > > Instructions to reproduce the issue are attached. The customer has included > his proposed fix.
Since the fix only is not included into SLE12SP2, I am providing a TEST package for it
https://ptf.suse.com/7391e193d1e52325386be385f94c5558/sles12-sp2/16988/x86_64/20190211-test
Please provide feedback.

(In reply to Robert Snow from comment #0) > This has been dupicated on sles 12 sp2, sp3, and sp4.
Hi Robert,
Could you make explicit what gdb versions you reproduced this for, by showing gdb --version?
Thanks, - Tom

(In reply to Robert Snow from comment #4) > (1) run many multi-thread processes (150 processes with 3 thread in each > thread group)
Hi Robert,
Can you post the source for the multi-thread process you used for reproducing the failure?
Thanks, - Tom

(In reply to Lidong Zhong from comment #10) > (In reply to Robert Snow from comment #0) > > This has been dupicated on sles 12 sp2, sp3, and sp4. > > > > Instructions to reproduce the issue are attached. The customer has included > > his proposed fix. > > Since the fix only is not included into SLE12SP2, I am providing a TEST > package > for it > > https://ptf.suse.com/7391e193d1e52325386be385f94c5558/sles12-sp2/16988/ > x86_64/20190211-test > > Please provide feedback.
The package contains the patch fixing the problem, but the test-case (attach-slow-waitpid.exp) was stripped from the patch.
I've run attach-slow-waitpid.exp with the gdb from SLE-12SP2, confirmed it failed, and then ran it with the gdb from TEST package, and confirmed it passed.

After confirming with the customer, they were duplicating this on the following version of SLES 12 SP3: gdb-8.0.1-2.3.2.s390x
Just to answer the question from comment#12, They were using pthread-nanosleep for reproducing the failure.
The customer does have an LTSS contract. They would like a PTF for a SLES 12 SP2 for s390x system.
Thanks.

(In reply to Samuel Snow from comment #14) > After confirming with the customer, they were duplicating this on the > following version of SLES 12 SP3: > gdb-8.0.1-2.3.2.s390x
That means they haven't installed all available maintenance updates. The gdb version on sle12-sp3 is gdb-8.2-2.9.4.s390x.
> The customer does have an LTSS contract. > They would like a PTF for a SLES 12 SP2 for s390x system.
See the TEST rpm from comment #10. Make the customer test that one to see if it fixes the problem. Then request a PTF.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #15) > (In reply to Samuel Snow from comment #14) > > After confirming with the customer, they were duplicating this on the > > following version of SLES 12 SP3: > > gdb-8.0.1-2.3.2.s390x > > That means they haven't installed all available maintenance updates. The > gdb version on sle12-sp3 is gdb-8.2-2.9.4.s390x. > > > The customer does have an LTSS contract. > > They would like a PTF for a SLES 12 SP2 for s390x system. > > See the TEST rpm from comment #10. Make the customer test that one to see > if it fixes the problem. Then request a PTF.
The rpm in the PTF from comment #10 is for x86_64. Will it work on s390x?

Here is the TEST package for s390x(sles12sp2)
https://ptf.suse.com/7391e193d1e52325386be385f94c5558/sles12-sp2/17021/s390x/20190214-test
After the customer finishes the test, I will provide a formal one.

(In reply to Samuel Snow from comment #16) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #15) > > (In reply to Samuel Snow from comment #14) > > > After confirming with the customer, they were duplicating this on the > > > following version of SLES 12 SP3: > > > gdb-8.0.1-2.3.2.s390x > > > > That means they haven't installed all available maintenance updates. The > > gdb version on sle12-sp3 is gdb-8.2-2.9.4.s390x. > > > > > The customer does have an LTSS contract. > > > They would like a PTF for a SLES 12 SP2 for s390x system. > > > > See the TEST rpm from comment #10. Make the customer test that one to see > > if it fixes the problem. Then request a PTF. > > The rpm in the PTF from comment #10 is for x86_64. Will it work on s390x?
True, sorry for the confusion. That now got rectified in comment #17.
But there's still the question of how they can have gdb 8.0 on an SP3 system. That can't be possible, except that they haven't installed all maintenance updates. Please ensure the customer does that.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #18) > But there's still the question of how they can have gdb 8.0 on an SP3 > system. That can't be possible, except that they haven't installed all > maintenance updates. Please ensure the customer does that.
The version that customer uses is released in GA. It seems the customer hasn't install any update yet.

The customer was able to use the TEST PTF with the following feedback:
1. The gstack command hang problem did not occur anymore with the test package. 2. The gstack command output now only shows back trace of one thread.
They provided an example of this problem -
(1) Original gdb v7 package, back trace of all threads are shown
sles12s2k:~ # rpm -q gdb gdb-7.11.1-8.38.1.s390x
sles12s2k:~ # ps -eflL |grep 1924
0 S root 1924 1 1924 0 3 80 0 - 37410 futex_ 09:11 pts/0 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 1924 1 2111 0 3 80 0 - 37410 hrtime 09:11 pts/0 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 1924 1 2112 0 3 80 0 - 37410 hrtime 09:11 pts/0 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
sles12s2k:~ # gstack 1924
Thread 3 (Thread 0x3ff943ff910 (LWP 2112)):
#0 0x000003ff94e1159c in ?? () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#1 0x0000000080001074 in func ()
#2 0x000003ff94e08b2a in start_thread () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#3 0x000003ff94ceecca in thread_start () from /lib64/libc.so.6
Thread 2 (Thread 0x3ff94bff910 (LWP 2111)):
#0 0x000003ff94e1159c in ?? () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#1 0x0000000080001074 in func ()
#2 0x000003ff94e08b2a in start_thread () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#3 0x000003ff94ceecca in thread_start () from /lib64/libc.so.6
Thread 1 (Thread 0x3ff94f79710 (LWP 1924)):
#0 0x000003ff94e09dc0 in pthread_join () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#1 0x00000000800012e0 in main ()
(2) Test Package gdb v8, only one thread is shown.
sles12s2k:~ # rpm -q gdb gdb-8.0.1-1.5.1.17021.1.TEST.1123234.s390x
sles12s2k:~ # gstack 1924
Thread 3 (Thread 0x3ff943ff910 (LWP 2112)):
#0 0x000003ff94e1159c in ?? () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#1 0x0000000080001074 in func ()
#2 0x000003ff94e08b2a in start_thread () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#3 0x000003ff94ceecca in thread_start () from /lib64/libc.so.6
I realized this problem is seen even with the gdb8.2-2.94 on SLES12SP4.
sles12s4k:~ # rpm -q gdb gdb-8.2-2.9.4.s390x
sles12s4k:~ # ps -eflL |grep 2915

bug.short_desc: crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges
bug.product: Beta SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP1

long_desc.thetext:
Microsot SQL team is running SQL TPC-E benchmark, we need to tune some kernel configuration parameters.
SLES15 version:
SPE-PURLEY-07:/usr/src # cat /etc/os-release NAME="SLES" VERSION="15-SP1" VERSION_ID="15.1" PRETTY_NAME="SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP1" ID="sles" ID_LIKE="suse" ANSI_COLOR="0;32" CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:suse:sles:15:sp1" SPE-PURLEY-07:/usr/src # uname -a Linux SPE-PURLEY-07 4.12.14-30-default #1 SMP Fri Jan 25 15:21:53 UTC 2019 (7f76697) x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
The repro is simple:
cd /usr/src/linux zcat /proc/config.gz > .config make oldconfig
we are getting the following errors:
HOSTCC scripts/basic/fixdep /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: file not recognized: file format not recognized collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status make[1]: *** [scripts/Makefile.host:107: scripts/basic/fixdep] Error 1 make: *** [Makefile:471: scripts_basic] Error 2
I think the best triaging information I was able to get was this issue with the elfutils recent change and not using binutils 2.32 https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=242682
we have only binutils-2.31-6.3.1.x86_64
This archlinux forum mentions a “patched” version of binutils v2.31 with a fix or to downgrade both elfutils and libelf.
My questions: - Have you seen this issue? - If yes, do you any fix for us to execute?
Hi Michael, since it mentioned binutils, I cc you

Yes, this issue is known. But it should only be visible in inconsistent systems, not in fully updated ones. See bug#1123601, where the reporter was using a system that used packages from a SLE15 SP1 tree that was in an intermediate state of rebuilding.
This should not happen for a fully built-through tree, and certainly not in a tree that was exposed to customers.
So, please tell us the exact version of glibc-devel as well.
Just to be sure, please also provide the output of:
% rpm -q --changelog binutils | head -n 5 % rpm -q --changelog glibc-devel | head -n 5

SPE-PURLEY-07:/opt/intel # rpm -q --changelog binutils | head -n 5 * Tue Aug 28 2018 matz@suse.com - Update to binutils-2_31-branch @e51abf7e3, minor bugfixes in the support for the X86_ISA_1_* notes. Adds patch binutils-2.31-branch.diff.gz . - Add binutils-revert-plt32-in-branches.diff on anything older SPE-PURLEY-07:/opt/intel # rpm -q --changelog glibc-devel | head -n 5 * Wed Nov 07 2018 schwab@suse.de - x86-haswell-string-flags.patch: Fix Haswell CPU string flags (bsc#1114984, BZ #23709) - pthread-cond-broadcast-waiters-after-spinning.patch: Fix waiters-after-spinning case (bsc#1114993, BZ #23538)
/lib64/libc-2.26.so
Hello All, any update on this bug?

There seems to be some inconsisteny with the package versions in the various Beta trees for SLE15-SP1, that might lead to this problem.
Essentially the binutils you have (with the Aug 28 2018 entry as most recent changelog) has rpm version 2.31-6.3.1. But it definitely is an old binutils version that is not able to handle the new crti.o file from newly compiled glibc.
Am I correct in assuming that you glibc-devel package is at version 2.26-15.5 (rpm -q glibc-devel)? If so, you have a glibc from Beta3 but binutils from Beta2, and that is not going to work.
If that is true then the problem is that the rpm version of the binutils package for Beta3 is 2.31-5.2, and that is _lower_ than from Beta2. So a normal update would have updated glibc, but not binutils, leading to this problem.
You can verify this by explicitely installing the other binutils version ('zypper in binutils=2.31-5.2' - maybe you need to select something to allow downgrading package versions). If that then works it's really just a problem with the rpm versions in the product trees.
For this rpm version problem I'm CCing some people who might know the cause. For those, there is this problem:
% ll /dist/SLP/SLE-15-SP1-Module-Basesystem-Beta*/x86_64/DVD1/x86_64/binutils-2* -r--r--r-- 1 root root 5978328 Oct 16 15:35 /dist/SLP/SLE-15-SP1-Module-Basesystem-Beta2/x86_64/DVD1/x86_64/binutils-2.31-6.3.1.x86_64.rpm -r--r--r-- 1 root root 5979428 Jan 28 15:49 /dist/SLP/SLE-15-SP1-Module-Basesystem-Beta3/x86_64/DVD1/x86_64/binutils-2.31-5.2.x86_64.rpm
Note how the rpm version is lower in the beta3 tree.

Thank you Mike, it worked.
I close the bug for now.

To use the Intel processor low-level driver, we need to enable "CONFIG_UNWINDER_FRAME_POINTER" in the SLES15 kernel. By default, this one is not enabled.
I followed the following instructions.
1. zcat /proc/config.gz > .config 2. edit .config to enable CONFIG_UNWINDER_FRAME_POINTER 3. then 4. make old config && make menuconfig && make -j && make -j modules && make modules_install && make install 5. the server is rebooted.
Now the kernel is not loaded due to the signature: For info, we had disabled secure boot.
comment #7 doesn't seem to have anything to do with crti.o or glibc or binutils, or compressed debug sections. Please create a new bug report for this.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2014-9482: libdwarf: use-after-free when parsing a crafted ELF file

long_desc.thetext: bugbot adjusting priority

Is this part of any product at all? libdwarf doesn't exist as source package in SLE12. bug.short_desc: gdb does not build reproducibly

long_desc.thetext:
most content in /usr/share/doc/packages/gdb-testresults differs for every build. I guess it should be split into a separate build like with gcc8-testresults or using the (still ugly) _multibuild feature in OBS, like glibc
Another approach could be to not package the testresults at all and just print them into the build log or into another side artifact.

Can you explain "other side artifact"? Is that a new OBS feature we can use to make the testresults accessible?
IMHO we want the ability to mark a sub-package "volatile" as to not trigger rebuilds of packages depending on it -- but nothing should depend on gdb-testresults so why exactly is that not reproducing an issue at all?

https://build.opensuse.org/package/binaries/openSUSE:Factory/gdb/standard already has '_buildenv' and 'rpmlint.log' as side-artifacts for download which do not influence pkg-diff calculation.
Not sure, if/how it is possible to make these in a build.
A "volatile" flag for subpackages could also help, because I think, currently all of gdb always gets republished and there are packages that BuildRequire gdb, which could create cycles.
> grep '^BuildRequires.*gdb$' */*.spec|cut -d/ -f1 |sort -u 389-ds cimple coreutils coreutils-testsuite crda cross-*-gcc7 gcc7 gcc7-testresults gcc8 glibc go1.* installation-images ldc libqt5-creator nemiver python-qt5 verilator

(In reply to Bernhard Wiedemann from comment #2) > https://build.opensuse.org/package/binaries/openSUSE:Factory/gdb/standard > already has '_buildenv' and 'rpmlint.log' as side-artifacts for download > which do not influence pkg-diff calculation. > > Not sure, if/how it is possible to make these in a build.
And make them "nicely" downloadable from the UI. Maybe we generally can add a _testresults "stream" a package build could store a tar archieve to for example?
> A "volatile" flag for subpackages could also help, > because I think, currently all of gdb always gets republished > and there are packages that BuildRequire gdb, which could create cycles. > > > grep '^BuildRequires.*gdb$' */*.spec|cut -d/ -f1 |sort -u > 389-ds > cimple > coreutils > coreutils-testsuite > crda > cross-*-gcc7 > gcc7 > gcc7-testresults > gcc8 > glibc > go1.* > installation-images > ldc > libqt5-creator > nemiver > python-qt5 > verilator
Awww, so re-building gets decided on whether _any_ of the sub-packages of the source package of a dependency changed? Ugh...
So a "volatile" package should then not being depend on.

bug.short_desc: ltrace shows no parameters when debuginfo installed

long_desc.thetext:
$ ltrace echo __libc_start_main([ "echo" ] <unfinished ...> getenv("POSIXLY_CORRECT") = nil strrchr("echo", '/') = nil setlocale(LC_ALL, "") = "cs_CZ.UTF-8" bindtextdomain("coreutils", "/usr/share/locale") = "/usr/share/locale" textdomain("coreutils") = "coreutils" ...
# zypper in coreutils-debuginfo
$ ltrace echo __libc_start_main([ "echo" ] <unfinished ...> getenv() = <void> strrchr() = <void> setlocale() = <void> bindtextdomain() = <void> textdomain() = <void> ...
Seems like ltrace DW support is broken somehow.

Created attachment 693723 potential fix
This fixes it for me. It really makes no sense to import functions from dwarf which have no prototype in there.
The only problem I see with the patch is that dwarf specs says "may have": "A subroutine entry declared with a function prototype style declaration may have a DW_AT_prototyped attribute, which is a flag."
Why does the debug info have no prototypes? That looks like a bug in the compiler output.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #3) > Jiri: can you look at coreutils-debuginfo if it contains getenv entries? > (Use readelf -wi for inspection).
Yes, it does. I checked it before, that's why the patch works :).
<1><1414>: Abbrev Number: 65 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <1415> DW_AT_external : 1 <1415> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1415> DW_AT_linkage_name: (indirect string, offset: 0x48b): getenv <1419> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x48b): getenv <141d> DW_AT_decl_file : 23 <141e> DW_AT_decl_line : 564
DW_AT_decl_file 23 is /usr/include/stdlib.h: 559-#endif 560- 561- 562-__BEGIN_NAMESPACE_STD 563-/* Return the value of envariable NAME, or NULL if it doesn't exist. */ 564:extern char *getenv (const char *__name) __THROW __nonnull ((1)) __wur; 565-__END_NAMESPACE_STD 566- 567-#ifdef __USE_GNU 568-/* This function is similar to the above but returns NULL if the

Hmpf. I wonder how that came into the debuginfo. As shown above a simple testcase merely calling getenv doesn't do that.
OTOH that's a side issue. It may or may not be regarded as quality of implementation issue of GCC to produce such debug entry, but it's certainly valid to do so (e.g. one could be interested in sort of minimal debug info that has top-level entities but nothing further, also no formal arguments; that is for instance what -g1 is doing actually). Ideally ltrace would work with both debug infos, so I think making it more accepting seems sensible.
I checked some GCC versions and they relieably seem to add the DW_AT_prototyped flag whenever the entity also has formal parameter children; so testing for that flag should be enough for ignoring those entries for ltrace purposes.
In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is factory different?

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #6) > In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is > factory different?
I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a preprocessed file I can analyze this.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > (In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #6) > > In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is > > factory different? > > I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a > preprocessed file I can analyze this.
I tried your example from comment #3. I need -O2 to have getenv in dw. gcc-5 behaves the same.
42.2 have debuginfo with prototypes too.
OTOH, gcc-6 on 42.2 does not put getenv into dw.

(In reply to Jiri Slaby from comment #9) > OTOH, gcc-6 on 42.2 does not put getenv into dw.
Wrong: gcc-6 on 42.2 DOES put getenv into dw, but without prototype: $ gcc-6 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <359> DW_AT_abstract_origin: <0x36a> <2><35d>: Abbrev Number: 0 <1><35e>: Abbrev Number: 22 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <35f> DW_AT_external : 1 <35f> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <35f> DW_AT_linkage_name: (indirect string, offset: 0x186): getenv <363> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x186): getenv <367> DW_AT_decl_file : 7 <368> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <1><36a>: Abbrev Number: 23 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <36b> DW_AT_external : 1 <36b> DW_AT_declaration : 1
gcc 4.8 puts in the prototype: gcc-4.8 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <2fb> DW_AT_type : <0x264> <2ff> DW_AT_external : 1 <2ff> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1><2ff>: Abbrev Number: 19 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <300> DW_AT_external : 1 <300> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x268): getenv <304> DW_AT_decl_file : 6 <305> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <307> DW_AT_prototyped : 1 <307> DW_AT_type : <0x8b> <30b> DW_AT_declaration : 1

For completeness, gcc 5 on factory: $ gcc-5 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <2f1> DW_AT_external : 1 <2f1> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1><2f1>: Abbrev Number: 18 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <2f2> DW_AT_external : 1 <2f2> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <2f2> DW_AT_linkage_name: (indirect string, offset: 0x28a): getenv <2f6> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x28a): getenv <2fa> DW_AT_decl_file : 6 <2fb> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <1><2fd>: Abbrev Number: 19 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <2fe> DW_AT_external : 1 <2fe> DW_AT_declaration : 1

And to fill the gap, 4.9 is still OK: $ gcc-4.9 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <2fb> DW_AT_type : <0x264> <2ff> DW_AT_external : 1 <2ff> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1><2ff>: Abbrev Number: 19 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <300> DW_AT_external : 1 <300> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x268): getenv <304> DW_AT_decl_file : 6 <305> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <307> DW_AT_prototyped : 1 <307> DW_AT_type : <0x8b> <30b> DW_AT_declaration : 1
So it has to be something new in gcc-5.

Created attachment 694994 preprocessed file
(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a > preprocessed file I can analyze this.
Attached.

(In reply to Jiri Slaby from comment #8) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > > (In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #6) > > > In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is > > > factory different? > > > > I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a > > preprocessed file I can analyze this. > > I tried your example from comment #3. I need -O2 to have getenv in dw. gcc-5 > behaves the same.
Oh wow. It never occured to me to try -g -O2 as producing more debug info (even if incomplete) than just -g. Okay I can reproduce, will poke at this a bit. Thanks.

It's a "feature" to implement DW_TAG_GNU_call_site / DW_TAG_GNU_call_site_parameter support. You get this non-prototyped decl also with -O0 if you enable -fvar-tracking. The non-prototyped form is the minimal info that is needed it seems.
It seems to be fixed somehow.

(In reply to Jiri Slaby from comment #1) > Created attachment 693723 [details] > potential fix
Reopening as this patch is still needed. No matter whether glibc-debuginfo is installed or not, it behaves the same. Important is how the code below is compiled (-g -Og needed).
Source: #include <stdio.h>
int main(void) { fwrite("a", 1, 1, stdout); fwrite("b", 1, 1, stdout); fwrite("\n", 1, 1, stdout);
return 0; }
Build: gcc tracer.c -Og -g
Without the patch: $ ltrace ./a.out fwrite() = <void> fwrite() = <void> fwrite(ab ) = <void> +++ exited (status 0) +++
With the patch: ltrace ./a.out fwrite("a", 1, 1, 0x7f049ee5b760) = 1 fwrite("b", 1, 1, 0x7f049ee5b760) = 1 fwrite("\n", 1, 1, 0x7f049ee5b760ab ) = 1 +++ exited (status 0) +++
I tried to build with all these flags, but the issue is not reproducible, so Og must enable some more: -fcombine-stack-adjustments -fcompare-elim -fcprop-registers -fdefer-pop -fforward-propagate -fguess-branch-probability -fipa-profile -fipa-pure-const -fipa-reference -fomit-frame-pointer -freorder-blocks -fshrink-wrap -fsplit-wide-types -ftree-builtin-call-dce -ftree-ccp -ftree-coalesce-vars -ftree-copy-prop -ftree-dce -ftree-dominator-opts -ftree-dse -ftree-fre -ftree-ch -ftree-sink -ftree-slsr -ftree-ter

bug.short_desc: -fstack-clash-protection writes beyond array bounds

long_desc.thetext:
When allocating a zero-length array with alloca or as a VLA the code produced by -fstack-clash-protection accesses the array beyond bounds. The failure can best be seen on armv7 (or targets without their own probe_stack insn) where a stack probe is destructive, and where it breaks glibc.
https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/Base:System/glibc/openSUSE_Factory_ARM/armv7l
The C standard says that VLA shall not have zero size, but a size of 1 is valid, and the default probe_stack expansion writes to a MEM of word_mode.

So we have to surround the code generated by the final
+ if (flag_stack_clash_protection) + emit_stack_probe (target);
with a compare against zero and jump.
SLE is affected as well.

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #1) > The C standard says that VLA shall not have zero size, but a size of 1 is > valid, and the default probe_stack expansion writes to a MEM of word_mode.
So the question is whether we at least align the allocation to word_mode which I doubt.
GCC supports zero length arrays, but it is unclear if it also supports zero length VLA.
ldconfig on aarch64 is also affected.
Hmpf. Indeed, some hardening is in order, aligning the size to wordmode and checking for zeroness. I'm going to work on that, but the labs conf interferes a small bit.

The generated code for probing "char zero[pad]":
mov r6, sp add r3, r3, #7 bic r3, r3, #7 cmp r3, #4096 bcc .L128 .L186: sub r3, r3, #4096 sub sp, sp, #4096 cmp r3, #4096 str r0, [sp, #8] bcs .L186 .L128: ldr r7, [fp, #-56] sub sp, sp, r3 mov r1, #0 add r3, sp, #8 mov r0, r3 str r0, [sp, #8]
The offset of #8 means that it overwrites a nearby variable.

For "char *dir = strdupa (aux_cache_name);" it generates an insn with unpredictable behavior:
mov r0, r5 bl strlen(PLT) add r3, r0, #15 add r2, r0, #1 bic r3, r3, #7 cmp r3, #4096 bcc .L281 .L320: sub r3, r3, #4096 sub sp, sp, #4096 cmp r3, #4096 str r0, [sp] bcs .L320 .L281: sub sp, sp, r3 ldr r1, [fp, #-172] mov r0, sp str r0, [r0], #7 <====== bic r0, r0, #7 bl memcpy(PLT)
cache.s:2116: Warning: source register same as write-back base
The latter is filed as PR82248.
so both arm 32 and 64bit are currently broken regardng that option?
It is unknown whether other architectures are affected.

As one data point: I was comparing the testresults (GCC testsuite) of all SLE11 architectures on gcc43 with this patch, they were clean. So either the testsuite doesn't contain a problematic alloca, or only aarch64 is affected. Are we caring for arm 32 bit?
Most likely none of them is testing zero-size VLA.
My home:matz2:clash-check project made enough progress on armv7l and aarch64 that I think I've fixed the problem, so gcc7 is submitted as SR #528941 now.
Is this now better?
Looks so.

bug.short_desc: Application stalls in Unwind function

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 743560 HANA profile
When throwing multiple exceptions (50++) in parallel, our HANA development observes that HANA can become extremely slow or completely hangs for a longer time on very large systems (UV300 / 32 sockets / 48 TiB). Their analysis shows that most of the time (90%) is spent in the Unwind function, as can be seen in the attached profile.
They currently try to mitigate the problem by avoiding exceptions as much as possible, but since the problem is still there and can heavily impact productive usage, they would like to understand the situation better.
When searching the web for similar issues, we came across this thread https://lists.freebsd.org/pipermail/freebsd-threads/2008-April/004262.html
with the related (invalid) bug entry https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=36030
Although invalid at that time, the bug more or less describes our current problem. Is there something where we could jointly follow up on? The system is running a recent SLE 12 SP1 and our colleagues suspect the situation to be impacted by larger environments.
Than you very much in advance!

I think the __dl_iterate_phdr bottleneck is known (can't find a glibc bugzilla tho). Given in your case we have many readers and no writers so a multi-reader/single-writer lock would be a convenient thing to have there. I've not seen such in glibcs infrastructure tho.
CCing glibc folks.
There's pthread_rwlock_* at least, so that's sth that could be used. Of course needs to move somewhere accessible from non-threaded glibc parts.
C++ exceptions are designed to be the exception, not the rule, thus are optimized for not being taken.

See https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/gcc/2013-05/msg00253.html for a lengthy discussion about lock contention and many calls to dl_iterate_phdr.
Due to the nature of unwinding together with dlopen/dlclose facilities we can't get rid of the locks itself. The about only ideas in that mail thread are revolving around thread-local or per-unwind-local caching of information and I personally don't see any other possibilities either. Those ideas are more or less theoretic, most have deep ABI implications.
Regarding mostly-read structures (comment #1): since glibc 2.12 (i.e. long before SLE-12) dl_iterate_phdr uses a write-specific lock:
int __dl_iterate_phdr (int (*callback) (struct dl_phdr_info *info, size_t size, void *data), void *data) { struct link_map *l; struct dl_phdr_info info; int ret = 0;
/* Make sure nobody modifies the list of loaded objects. */ __rtld_lock_lock_recursive (GL(dl_load_write_lock)); __libc_cleanup_push (cancel_handler, NULL); ...
But even though this lock is specific for the write path (i.e. the dlopen/close routines take it only before modifying any of the interesting data structures), the above call simply uses __rtld_lock_lock_recursive, which, if I'm understanding the various glibc internal headers correctly, doesn't make a difference between readers and writers.
If so, then the above locking call synchronizes also between different callers of dl_iterate_phdr, without any need to do so, as this function only reads.
So, yes, this specific instance of overly blocky dl_iterate_phdr might be solvable by using proper read/write locks. Andreas, any opinion?
Libc locks are simple (recursive) mutexes, if you need finer graned locking you need to use separate locks.
There is also __libc_rwlock_t, but it lacks infrastructure to be usable from rtld.
Ah, yes, I see. Using it for the dl_load_write_lock would most probably help this specific use case quite some. Would be cool to work on getting the infrastructure in place for this.

Replacing just dl_load_write_lock with a rwlock won't help because that lock is only held when the list of loaded objects is about to be modified. This is already the minimum required extent where __dl_iterate_phdr needs to be locked out.

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #10) > Replacing just dl_load_write_lock with a rwlock won't help because that lock > is only held when the list of loaded objects is about to be modified. This > is already the minimum required extent where __dl_iterate_phdr needs to be > locked out.
It will help removing the lock contention on simultaneous invocations of __dl_iterate_phdr because that function only needs to take a read lock.

Just for completeness let me also mention these bugreports discussing this and related problems: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71744 (Concurrently throwing exceptions is not scalable, but not testcase just general discussion) and https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=2377 which contains a testcase involving exceptions, threads and dlopen/close (the latter being the reason for the locks).

Sorry for the flurry of comments :) From the above glibc thread which contains the testcase the author tried a hack with an rwlock and didn't see performance improvements with it (on the testcase), as also rwlocks seem to hold a lock (and not using atomics?), for a short time, but still a synchronization point.
In any case, we should try nevertheless and make SAP try that then.
I don't think dl_iterate_phdr can usefully be made to run in parallel without fixing the cache usage in the libgcc unwinder.
Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #16) > Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache > either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which > gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?
Thank you Michael (and of course Andreas and Richard), this discussion already looks very promising! We are going to check what HANA version was used in the specific customer case, as the gcc/libgcc version depends on the version used, and our colleagues are trying to prepare a comparable test system. Since we are using the toolchain module, shouldn't the newest libgcc_s1-package be sufficient?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #16) > Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache > either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which > gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?
So the cache relies on an implementation detail (we never get concurrent invocations of the _Unwind_IteratePhdrCallback due to the lock in the glibc implementation). Sth that seems worth to fix anyway for correctness, like by making it thread-local or by making cache operations atomic or wrapped inside a lock (eh...). I guess the cache might not work very well with threads anyhow.
L3:49392 is now handled by Vasilis Liaskovitis.

Severity and priority are not set correctly. It's a very complicated issue and it's very old and known since a long time and occurs only when using exceptions in an arguably wrong way. It can't be major, and certainly is not of high priority. In fact there's actually no bug. It's a feature request really.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #20) > Severity and priority are not set correctly. It's a very complicated issue > and it's very old and known since a long time and occurs only when using > exceptions in an arguably wrong way. It can't be major, and certainly is > not of high priority. In fact there's actually no bug. It's a feature > request really.
OK, it seems this could be handled as a FATE then, and is outside of L3 scope. I marked this as enhancement and medium priority, but feel free to change. I will close the L3 if there are no objections.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #21) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #20) > > OK, it seems this could be handled as a FATE then, and is outside of L3 > scope. I marked this as enhancement and medium priority, but feel free to > change. I will close the L3 if there are no objections.
It could be handled as L3-question as well, I believe. The thing is, eventually we might want to give SAP some TEST packages for them to try, which are normally built by L3; it just isn't very urgent. Would that work for you to leave L3 involved in this one?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #22) > It could be handled as L3-question as well, I believe. The thing is, > eventually we might want to give SAP some TEST packages for them to try, > which are normally built by L3; it just isn't very urgent. Would that work > for you to leave L3 involved in this one?
Sure that works, I can leave L3 open.
If you think it will take a long time (e.g. more than 4-6 weeks) to prepare TEST packages, as it is not urgent, I can also close and re-open L3 when you have the packages for them to try.
@Michael I am assigning this to you. Feel free to re-assign though.
@Michael, let me know if there is a candidate patch to be tested here - I can then build an L3 for the partner to test.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #25) > @Michael, let me know if there is a candidate patch to be tested here - I > can then build an L3 for the partner to test.
I will, but I doubt it'll happen this year.

@Michael, any chance to get a test package in the next weeks?
If a patch is not likely to happen in Q1, I 'll close the L3 and re-open it once you have a patch for testing. The bug can stay open of course.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #27) > @Michael, any chance to get a test package in the next weeks?
Pfew, I don't know. Let's be realistic and say no.
> If a patch is not likely to happen in Q1, I 'll close the L3 and re-open it > once you have a patch for testing. The bug can stay open of course.
Okay, then let's do that.

bug.short_desc: binutils: enable as-needed by default

long_desc.thetext:
Inside the build service environment created by /usr/bin/build, $SUSE_ASNEEDED is set and ld behaves as if it were passed -Wl,--as-needed. Outside that box, in a "normal" system, SUSE_ASNEEDED=0. This behavior is puzzling to some people every now and then. https://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-packaging/2017-05/msg00000.html
I think we should always enable --as-needed for the openSUSE "normal" system.
Debian systems also behave such that an incorrect -l order leads to builds stopping.
Yeah, initially we didn't want this because there was much code in the wild that got it wrong. That time has long gone, so I agree. I'll do the change with next binutils update.
But do we really want to deviate from upstream here?

Well, we already deviate in half of Geeko land. The first maxime is therefore to make it behave equal again across SUSE products. Secondarily is to have a look at what other distros do, and evaluate whether to go with the not-upstream-default behavior. Besides Debian, it would appear that Gentoo also has as-needed enabled. as-needed is one of many strategies to drop unnecessary dependencies and to also find programming errors due to effects of link order sensitiviy (missing libs, etc.). I anecdotally remember solaris ld being link-order-sensitive (but not as-needy) too, so that's that.
In other words, it just helps me and others make somewhat better software.
Actually we can propose to make that change upstream as well, then we wouldn't deviate :-)
